| Debian Install and configuration |


This page is divided into 5 categories:
1#    Debian GNU/Linux 8 / Jessie installation/configuration guide - MATE Desktop  - with X11.
2#    Debian GNU/Linux 8 / Jessie - Server configuration - headless, no X11.
3#    RaspberryPi configuration - headless, no X11.
4#    Android links / notes.
5#    Other Linux/Unix devices configurations.

Page file size is: 1 06 899 bytes / 1.0 MB and was last updated on: Thursday, 06 October 2016

 Press Ctrl + F5 / Shift + Ctrl + F5 in your web browser to force cache purge and get up to date version.

#    Debian GNU/Linux 8 / Jessie Installation Guide - MATE Desktop
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Please not that there is no OFFICIAL (up to date) support for Flash on machines with 32-bit / i386 processor architecture.

https://get.adobe.com/flashplayer/
NOTE: Adobe Flash Player 11.2 will be the last version to target Linux as a supported platform. Adobe will continue to provide security backports to Flash Player 11.2 for Linux.
http://arstechnica.com/security/2015/07/firefox-blacklists-flash-player-due-to-unpatched-0-day-vulnerabilities/




Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Alternative to Windows = Linux - Debian Free OS on your PC
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
What is Linux?

Unix-like computer operating system (OS) assembled under the model of free and open-source software development and distribution.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux


What is a Raspberry Pi?
The Raspberry Pi is a low cost, credit-card sized computer that plugs into a computer monitor or TV, and uses a standard keyboard and mouse.
https://www.raspberrypi.org/help/what-is-a-raspberry-pi/


What is Debian?
The Debian Project is an association of individuals who have made common cause to create a free operating system.
https://www.debian.org/intro/about


Replace your out of date Windows XP or Vista/7/8 OS with alternative FREE open source OS called Debian GNU/Linux.
More on the new version of FREE Windows 10 (Home/Professional)
http://arstechnica.co.uk/information-technology/2015/08/windows-10-doesnt-offer-much-privacy-by-default-heres-how-to-fix-it/

http://www.theregister.co.uk/2015/08/03/windows_10_privacy_defaults/


At first it looks complicated like everything new, but once you know your way around it, its similar to Windows / Mac OSX and it's FREE compare to upgrading your
current OS and you will get very reliable, stable operating system that is used by many big companies including BA. (BA will be deploying different distro called RedHat.)

I have first tried Free/OpenBSD about 10 years ago, then RedHat, Ubuntu, CentOS and end up with Debian. More on Linux distributions here:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux_distributio

My girlfriend has been happy user for past 4 years without any problems, my old man is in his second year, but I would say it is only suited for someone who is not afraid to learn something new
(similar to learn how to use Mac OSX), as like with your car, it needs bit of maintenance that may need users interaction from time to time. There is lots of FREE literature as well:

With the Debian GNU/Linux - Jessie distribution you will get FREE alternative to Microsoft Office (LibreOffice) and other FREE programs for browsing the Internet
(Google Chrome and others), watching (VLC, SMPlayer)/ downloading (Torrent client), streaming your Live TV (TVHeadend-server) around your house or movies
to compatible devices (miniDLNA-server), Skype, TeamViewer, run your own VPN server (OpenVPN), etc.


The only disadvantage is that if you have "purchased" any Windows applications, they may (WINdows Emulator permitting) not work under Debian GNU/Linux, but there is a good
chance that there is an FREE alternative available.

In order to install this OS, all the data on your old PC/Laptop need to be backed up to external hard disk if you do not want to loose it as all data will be wiped off during the installation.







Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    What will you need - Itinerary  - as of Wednesday, 09 March 2016
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This instructions are for debian-8.3.0-i386-amd64-source-DVD-1.iso please check over here for latest updates
of the multi arch DVD.

Debian on CDs - Frequently Asked Questions

#A] Blank DVD disc to burn the  3.7GB image to. (PC World VERBATIM 16x Speed DVD-R Blank DVDs =£3.99)
        I be happy to provide you with one for FREE.

#B] FREE ISO image (debian-8.3.0-i386-amd64-source-DVD-1.iso) of the Debian OS, please check
        (I choose multi-arch as it can be used to install both 32 / 64 bit processor architectures and you do not have
        to burn 2 DVD's if you not sure what processor architecture you have).

#C] Checksum for the ISO image to confirm that it has been downloaded correctly. I prefer SHA512 - SHA512SUMS

#D] FREE Windows Software to check checksum of the downloaded ISO image. I preferred HashTab.
        Copy the hash for the debian-8.3.0-i386-amd64-source-DVD-1.iso from the SHA512SUMS file (highlight it and press Ctrl+C):
        ad3bed1959bd464b8c0965bd59df9d8be4b0de9182fa1791c43ecefa2cd1c8132b01ad7bbb263856e2b694ac815c04b3d7e235b5f7320ddc9ed894d93e27e74e
        Right click in the debian-8.3.0-i386-amd64-source-DVD-1.iso file and in 

#E] FREE Windows software to burn the ISO to DVD disc. Infra Recorder as recommended by Ubuntu see how to or ImgBurn with screenshots on how to do it.

#F] FREE Windows software to check what formats is your CD/DVD/BD - Drive capable of reading/writing.  Nero InfoTool | VSO Inspector | CD/DVD Device Capabilities Viewer | DVD Identifier | ImgBurn

#G] Ethernet cable - to connect with your router so we do not have to deal with Wi-Fi drivers that may be missing. (PC World 10m RJ45toRJ45 Cat6 =£14.99)
        Check that you do not have one that come with your xDSL router.

#H] External USB DVD Writer in case your PC does not have one. (PC World from £19.99).

#I] FREE Debian Bible book, links below.

Free book a Debian Bible: Debian Jessie from Discovery to Mastery by Raphaël Hertzog
https://debian-handbook.info/get/now/
English PDF (28.5 Mb) | English EPUB (4.6 Mb) | English Mobipocket (12.4 Mb)

# To view the book in html (sudo apt-get install debian-handbook)
ls -ila /usr/share/doc/debian-handbook/
file:///usr/share/doc/debian-handbook/html/en-US/index.html


Should you need any help, please contact me/send picture of your error message using Telegram.org app
(works on Android, iPhone, iPad, WP, Web, PC, Mac, Linux) on this Private Channel.


Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Installation process  - as of Wednesday, 09 March 2016
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


#0 Secure Boot:  https://debianmanual.github.io/stretch.9/
or you can try it with Secure Boot ON as per instructions over here
https://burtness.wordpress.com/2014/02/08/secure-boot-with-debian-testing/

#0 Boot Mode = UEFI or Legacy (BIOS)
If this is your first installation and your are not sure, choose "Legacy"


#0 SATA Operation = AHCI or IRRT
- AHCI has a higher performance than ATA.
- AHCI is a requirement for the TRIM command.
- AHCI is required for self encrypting hard drives
 
Dell E4200:
ATA, AHCI, IRRT (Intel Rapid Restore Technology)

In IRRT the laptop fail when trying to install the OS from my USB stick with msg.:
[!!] Partition disks
There was a problem reading data from the CD-ROM. Please make sure it is in the drive. If
retrying does not work, you should check the integrity of your CD-ROM.
Failed to copy file from CD-ROM. Retry?




#1 BIOS: Boot from CD/DVD drive option:
Dell - keep pressing F12 key - pick CD/DVD/CD-RW Drive from the menu






#2    When you successfully boot up from the DVD disc, you will see these options:
Debian GNU/Linux installer boot menu:

# Install - this is 32bit console installation
# 64 bit install - this is 64bit console installation

# Graphical install - 32bit graphical installation
# 64 bit graphical install - is 64bit graphical installation






This is what you see if you try to install 64 bit (x86-64) version on PC/laptop with only 32 bit
(i686) processor:

This kernel requires an x86-64 CPU, but only detected an i686 CPU.
Unable to boot - please use a kernel appropriate for you CPU.
So reboot your PC/laptop and start again, but choose "Install" or "Graphic install" for
32 bit processor.





#3    Select a language - Language: "English - English"



#4    Select your location - Country, territory or area: "United Kingdom"



#5    Configure the keyboard - Keymap to use: "British English" aka QWERTY



Detect and mount CD-ROM - AUTOMATIC
Load installer components from CD - AUTOMATIC


#6    Detect network hardware - Load missing firmware from removable media? Select "No"
- will install the Wi-Fi adapter later

If you selected "Yes"  connect USB/floppy (FAT16/FAT32 formatted) WITH THE REQUIRED FILES
if you want to install it now or you have not got and Ethernet port/adapter - newer laptops.


Configure the network - AUTOMATIC it will check that there is Internet connection working for
both DHCP IPv4 / IPv6


#7    Configure the network - Hostname: "Pick one, I always use model name/number
of the pc/laptop".



#8    Configure the network - Domain name - Leave "empty"



#9    Set up users and password - Root password: "Pick your own password".



#10    Set up users and password - Full name for the the new user:  Lets say "Donald Trump"
I like to keep it simple, no need to divulge too much information :) so simple "name" will do.



#11    Set up users and password - Username for your account:  Let's say "donald"



#12    Set up users and password - Choose a password for the new users:
"Pick your own, but different than the one for the root account set up earlier".



Configure the clock - AUTOMATIC
Detect disk - AUTOMATIC

#13    Partition disks - Partitioning method: Leave default "Guided - use entire disk"



#14    Partition disks - Select disk to partition:
Main hdd should be marked as (0,0,0) (sda) in my case I only have one.



#15    Partition disks - Partitioning scheme: Leave default "All files in one partition
(recommended for new users)".



#16    Partition disks - Leave default "Finish partitioning and write changes to disk"
Before you hit "Continue" button check that it's the right hdd - (sda)



#17    Partition disks - Write the changes to disks? - Select "Yes"



Install the base system - AUTOMATIC "Installing the base system" MAY TAKE A WHILE
DEPENDING ON THE SPEED OF YOUR HARD DRIVE.

Main is 5400rpm so its well slow, but its 11 yeas old laptop, it can even be worse first
HDD ware spinning at 1200rpm.

There are drives that spins at 7200rpm, fast one spinning at 10000rpm and super fast one
spinning at 15000rpm.
 

#18    Configure the package manager - Use a network mirror? Select "Yes"



#19    Configure the package manager - Debian archive mirror country: Select "United Kingdom"



#20    Configure the package manager - Debian archive mirror: "ftp.uk.debian.org"



#21    Configure the package manager - HTTP proxy information (blank for none): Leave "empty"



Configure the package manager  - AUTOMATIC - Configuring apt "Retrieving file 1 of 5"
Select and install software - will take few seconds - AUTOMATIC - "Retrieving file 11 of 14
(50 s remaining) ...


#22    Configuring popularity-contest - Participate in the package usage survey? - Leave default: "No".



#23    Software selection - Choose software to install:
I choose Xfce on this installation as my laptop only has 512 of RAM, but I prefer "MATE" on my machine.

Don't forget to "tick" the "SSH server" so you can connect to it):



Select and install software - AUTOMATIC Retrieving file 1183 (21 min remaining) you will hear
your DVD drive reading from the DVD Disc

Time to have a cup of tea  or coffee :) this will take a while

Bialetti Venus Induction Espresso Maker
https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B0009Q1DSS/

...... how about Cuban Coffee:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=StDFjab62Vs
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gkNSTxPZDvg
https://desdeesteladodelaisla.wordpress.com/2014/07/28/tostar-pilar-y-colar-cafe/
http://cdn1.matadornetwork.com/blogs/2/2015/05/cuba-en-los-80-2.jpg
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OIaIwYHn1nQ&ebc=ANyPxKosrbXvCNZxhHkc0D2y_bHmwU296Ipituck-n07saLnD44H_j0x0cxMiut3fYDXZYKj09zIRx5wwlVLRkM3uDGkmY6HoQ




#24    Install GRUB boot loader on the hard disk - Install the GRUB boot loader to the master
boot record?: Select "Yes"



#25    Install GRUB boot loader on the hard disk - Device for boot loader installation: Select
your hdd "/dev/sda ..."



#26    Finish the installation - Installation complete: DVD disc will eject the DVD drive and your
machine will reboot.



Congratulation, 26 steps and you have a working Linux Debian Jessie OS.


#27    Once your laptop/PC restarted you will see the GRUB screen, leave it as it is:
" *Debian GNU/Linux" in few second it will start booting up to OS,
unless you pressed any keys then you may have to press "Enter"



#28    Before you login:
Top right change from "Default Xsession" to "Xfce Session" if you've installed Xfce as your desktop







Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# SSH into your newly installed machine from another
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# On Linux:
ssh donald@192.168.1.2
# For IPv6
ssh -6 donald@2001:470:b:227::1

# On Mac:
ssh donald@192.168.1.2


#On Windows: you will need to download PuTTY: a free SSH and Telnet client
"C:\Program Files\putty-0.62\putty.exe" -ssh -P 22222 pi@192.168.1.3 -pw raspberry

# This will create Web Tunnel
"C:\Program Files\putty-0.62\putty.exe" -ssh -D 4096 -P 22222 pi@192.168.1.3 -pw raspberry


# Generate strong keys RSA 4096/8192 bit or Ed25519 in size "ON YOUR PC"
ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -C "rsa.4096@MyPC" -o -a 10000


# Copy the key to SERVER
ssh-copy-id donald@80.180.90.160 -p22022
ssh-copy-id -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub "donald@80.180.90.160 -p22022"









Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Root login
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
We now need to make some configuration, I prefer to work from the Terminal Window aka shell
as it's easier and quicker.

# To gain ROOT access type in shell:
su
Enter your "Root password" created in step #9 of the installation process

You will see "#" at and of the line:
root@SVP112A1CM:/home/donald#




#NOTES
donald@SVP112A1CM:~$ su
Password:
root@SVP112A1CM:/home/donald#



# To enable Unlimited Scrollback in console instead of 512 lines.
Edit -> Profile Preference -> Scrolling - TICK - Unlimited



Back to Top...

#    Nano Editor tutorial - TODO
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ctrl +K delete current line
Ctrl+W search
Ctrl+O save the file
Ctrl+X exit

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Installing software / programs or Applications on Debian
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1# via Command Line / Command Prompt / shell [THIS IS MY PROFFERED METHOD]  ...
    a) APT-GET - sudo apt-get install nameofthepackage
    b) DPKG - Downloading *.deb file - sudo dpkg -i nameofthepackage.deb
    c) SOURCE/COMPILING - *tar / *tar.gz /
    d) GIT - Downloading from GIT - git clone http://



2# via GUI
    a) called Synaptic / Synaptic Package Manager [NEVER TRIED IT].
    b) GNOME-Software - NOT AVAILABLE, maybe in Debian 9?
    c) Software Center only available in Debian 7 Wheezy or Ubuntu!




Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Configure sources.list
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
So we can install programs or if you want applications via shell / Command Prompt or via graphic user
interface "Synaptic Package Manager" we need configure Debian repositories in sources.list file.

The Debian GNU/Linux FAQ - Chapter 8 - The Debian package management tools
https://www.debian.org/doc/manuals/debian-faq/ch-pkgtools.en.html


# Make a backup of the original
cp /etc/apt/sources.list /etc/apt/sources.list.ORIGINAL

# Let's change it to this:
nano /etc/apt/sources.list
###############################################################

# Security updates
deb http://security.debian.org/ jessie/updates main contrib non-free
deb-src http://security.debian.org/ jessie/updates main contrib non-free

# Base repository
deb http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian/ jessie main non-free contrib
deb-src http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian/ jessie main non-free contrib

# Stable updates - Jessie
# jessie-updates, previously known as 'volatile'
deb http://ftp.debian.org/debian jessie-updates main contrib non-free
deb-src http://ftp.debian.org/debian jessie-updates main contrib non-free

# Stable backports - Jessie
deb http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian jessie-backports main contrib non-free
deb-src http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian jessie-backports main contrib non-free

###############################################################

# Multimedia Stable amd64, armel, armhf, i386, kfreebsd-amd64, kfreebsd-i386, mips, mipsel and powerpc packages
deb http://www.deb-multimedia.org jessie main non-free

# Multimedia Stable backports amd64, armel, armhf, i386, kfreebsd-amd64, kfreebsd-i386, mips, mipsel and powerpc packages
deb http://www.deb-multimedia.org jessie-backports main


# Multimedia Unstable - SID amd64, arm64, armel, armhf, i386, kfreebsd-amd64, kfreebsd-i386, mips, mipsel, powerpc and sparc packages.
#deb http://www.deb-multimedia.org sid main non-free
#deb-src http://www.deb-multimedia.org sid main


###############################################################

# Proposed Updates
#deb http://ftp.debian.org/debian jessie-proposed-updates main contrib non-free

# Unstable - SID
#deb http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian unstable main contrib non-free
#deb-src http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian unstable main contrib non-free

# SID
#deb http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian/ sid main non-free contrib

# Testing - Stretch
#deb http://ftp.debian.org/debian testing main contrib non-free
#deb-src http://ftp.debian.org/debian testing main contrib non-free

# Experimental
#deb http://ftp.debian.org/debian experimental main contrib non-free
###############################################################



#     To stop APT-GET complaining about the missing GPG key when updating download deb-multimedia-keyring
W: GPG error: http://www.deb-multimedia.org jessie InRelease: The following signatures couldn't be verified because the public key is not available: NO_PUBKEY 5C808C2B65558117
W: GPG error: http://www.deb-multimedia.org jessie-backports InRelease: The following signatures couldn't be verified because the public key is not available: NO_PUBKEY 5C808C2B65558117

# Download latest deb-multimedia-keyring
apt-get update
apt-get install deb-multimedia-keyring







NOTES:
# This will install the unstable version of the package, and try to meet any dependencies from Stable. This may not work, but it will tell you why:
sudo apt-get install package/unstable

# This will install the Unstable version of the package, and try to meet any dependencies from Unstable. This may produce better results.
sudo apt-get install -t unstable package

# The packages can only be installed by typing
sudo aptitude install package/experimental

# The following command REinstalls postfix even if it is already present:
sudo apt --reinstall install postfix
sudo aptitude reinstall postfix



# Lets see what we have in our repo file
cat /etc/apt/sources.list
##############################################################
#

# deb-src cdrom:[Debian GNU/Linux 8.3.0 _Jessie_ - Official Multi-architecture i386/amd64/source DVD #1 20160123-22:17]/ jessie main
# deb cdrom:[Debian GNU/Linux 8.3.0 _Jessie_ - Official Multi-architecture i386/amd64/source DVD #1 20160123-22:17]/ jessie main
#

deb-src cdrom:[Debian GNU/Linux 8.3.0 _Jessie_ - Official Multi-architecture i386/amd64/source DVD #1 20160123-22:17]/ jessie main
deb cdrom:[Debian GNU/Linux 8.3.0 _Jessie_ - Official Multi-architecture i386/amd64/source DVD #1 20160123-22:17]/ jessie main


deb http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian/ jessie main
deb-src http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian/ jessie main

deb http://security.debian.org/ jessie/updates main
deb-src http://security.debian.org/ jessie/updates main

# jessie-updates, previously known as 'volatile'
deb http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian/ jessie-updates main
deb-src http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian/ jessie-updates main
##############################################################

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Add Multiarch support
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch
https://wiki.debian.org/Multiarch/HOWTO

Multiarch is the term being used to refer to the capability of a system to install and run applications of multiple different binary targets on the same system.


# Check
dpkg --print-foreign-architectures
sudo dpkg --print-foreign-architectures

# Add architecture
sudo dpkg --add-architecture i386
sudo dpkg --add-architecture <arch>

#
sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get upgrade



dpkg -l | grep i386
sudo apt-get purge <package-name>


# Example of installation of i386 package on amd64 system
sudo apt-get install package:architecture
sudo apt-get install links:i386

Debian 7 “Wheezy” from 26th of April 2016 to 31st of May 2018
sudo nano /etc/apt/sources.list
###############################################################
deb http://httpredir.debian.org/debian/ wheezy main contrib non-free
deb-src http://httpredir.debian.org/debian/ wheezy main contrib non-free

deb http://security.debian.org/ wheezy/updates main contrib non-free
deb-src http://security.debian.org/ wheezy/updates main contrib non-free

deb http://httpredir.debian.org/debian/ wheezy-updates main contrib non-free
deb-src http://httpredir.debian.org/debian/ wheezy-updates main contrib non-free
###############################################################

nano /etc/apt/preferences
########################################################################
#Package: *
#Pin: release  a=stable
#Pin-Priority: 800

#Package: *
#Pin: release a=jessie-backports
#Pin-Priority: 700

#Package: *
#Pin: origin *.deb-multimedia.org
#Pin-Priority: 600
 
#Package: *
#Pin: release  a=testing
#Pin-Priority: 499
 
#Package: *
#Pin: release a=unstable
#Pin-Priority: 200

#Package: *
#Pin: release a=experimental
#Pin-Priority: 100
########################################################################

apt-get update && apt-get upgrade


NOTES:
sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get upgrade

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Unattended Upgrades
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://wiki.debian.org/UnattendedUpgrades


apt-get install unattended-upgrades apt-listchanges -y



nano /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/50unattended-upgrades
########################################################################
# Uncomment the line below near bottom of the file so it looks like this:
Unattended-Upgrade::Mail "root";
########################################################################

# Enable Autostratup - change to "YES"
dpkg-reconfigure -plow unattended-upgrades



Creating config file /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/20auto-upgrades with new version
update-rc.d: warning: start and stop actions are no longer supported; falling back to defaults



# Check to see if "20auto-upgrades" was created in previous step
cat /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/20auto-upgrades
########################################################################
APT::Periodic::Update-Package-Lists "1";
APT::Periodic::Unattended-Upgrade "1";
########################################################################




# Add the bellow:
nano /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/02periodic
########################################################################
# Add the lines below:
// Control parameters for cron jobs by /etc/cron.daily/apt //


// Enable the update/upgrade script (0=disable)
APT::Periodic::Enable "1";


// Do "apt-get update" automatically every n-days (0=disable)
APT::Periodic::Update-Package-Lists "1";


// Do "apt-get upgrade --download-only" every n-days (0=disable)
APT::Periodic::Download-Upgradeable-Packages "1";


// Run the "unattended-upgrade" security upgrade script
// every n-days (0=disabled)
// Requires the package "unattended-upgrades" and will write
// a log in /var/log/unattended-upgrades
APT::Periodic::Unattended-Upgrade "1";


// Do "apt-get autoclean" every n-days (0=disable)
APT::Periodic::AutocleanInterval "1";


// Send report mail to root
//     0:  no report             (or null string)
//     1:  progress report       (actually any string)
//     2:  + command outputs     (remove -qq, remove 2>/dev/null, add -d)
//     3:  + trace on
APT::Periodic::Verbose "2";
########################################################################





nano /etc/apt/listchanges.conf
########################################################################
[apt]
frontend=pager
email_address=root

# Change to 1 from 0
confirm=1
save_seen=/var/lib/apt/listchanges.db

# Change from "news" to "both"
which=both
########################################################################
apt-get update && apt-get upgrade

#    Essential software first - MATE
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sudo - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/sudo Provide limited super user privileges to specific users
mc - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/mc Midnight Commander - a powerful file manager
htop - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/htop interactive processes viewer
# Backports = gnome-commander - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/gnome-commander nice and fast file manager for the GNOME desktop
debian-handbook - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/debian-handbook reference book for Debian users and system administrators
apt-show-versions - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/apt-show-versions lists available package versions with distribution
gnome-nettool - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/gnome-nettool network information tool for GNOME
geany - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/geany  fast and lightweight IDE
gksu - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/gksu graphical front-end to su and sudo
gnome-system-tools - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/gnome-system-tools Cross-platform configuration utilities for GNOME
gdebi - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/gdebi simple tool to view and install deb files - GNOME GUI
xpdf - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/xpdf Portable Document Format (PDF) reader
curl - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/curl command line tool for transferring data with URL syntax
aria2 - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/aria2 High speed download utility
gstm - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/gstm SSH tunnel manager for GNOME
vdpau-va-driver - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/vdpau-va-driver VDPAU-based backend for VA API
# Backports = keepassx - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/keepassx Cross Platform Password Manager
sshfs - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/sshfs filesystem client based on SSH File Transfer Protocol
libsmbios2 - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/libsmbios2 Provide access to (SM)BIOS information -- dynamic library
hwinfo - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/hwinfo hwinfo is the hardware detection tool used in SuSE Linux.
smartmontools - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/smartmontools control and monitor storage systems using S.M.A.R.T.
lshw - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/lshw information about hardware configuration
lshw-gtk - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/lshw-gtk graphical information about hardware configuration
chromium-bsu - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/chromium-bsu fast paced, arcade-style, scrolling space shooter
transmission - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/transmission lightweight BitTorrent client
inxi - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/inxi full featured system information script
ntpdate - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/ntpdate client for setting system time from NTP servers
brasero - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/brasero CD/DVD burning application for GNOME -

apt-get install sudo mc htop debian-handbook apt-show-versions gnome-nettool geany gksu gnome-system-tools gdebi xpdf curl aria2 gstm vdpau-va-driver sshfs smbios-utils libsmbios-bin libsmbios2 hwinfo smartmontools lshw lshw-gtk chromium-bsu transmission inxi ntpdate brasero gconf-editor --assume-yes
apt-get -f install





gconf-editor - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/gconf-editor editor for the GConf configuration system

apt-get install gconf-editor --assume-yes
apt-get -f install






# From Backports
keepassx - https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/keepassx Cross Platform Password Manager
gnome-commander - https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/gnome-commander nice and fast file manager for the GNOME desktop
geany - https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/geany fast and lightweight IDE
smartmontools -  https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/smartmontools control and monitor storage systems using S.M.A.R.T.
axel - https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/axel light command line download accelerator
easytag - https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/easytag GTK+ editor for audio file tags

apt-get -t jessie-backports install keepassx gnome-commander geany smartmontools axel easytag exfat-fuse exfat-utils --assume-yes
apt-get -f install



ls -ila /usr/share/doc/debian-handbook/
file:///usr/share/doc/debian-handbook/html/en-US/index.html



sudo apt-get --download-only --reinstall install axel


exFat:
https://packages.debian.org/jessie/exfat-fuse
https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/exfat-fuse
https://packages.debian.org/jessie/exfat-utils
https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/exfat-utils

sudo apt-get install exfat-fuse exfat-utils
sudo mkdir /media/exfat
sudo mount -t exfat /dev/sdc1 /media/exfat
sudo umount /dev/sdc1

Generic STORAGE DEVICE (9407)
64 GB (63,864,569,856 bytes)
Master Boot Record
000000024994
/dev/sdc1
HPFS/NTFS
exFAT (version 1.0) — Not Mounted

#    Now we are ready to install some software. This I have found most frustrating coming from Micro$oft Windows to Linux,
I did not know the names of programs that will playing music, move files around play videos, DVDs etc.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
So here are my favourites: TODO

alacarte - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/alacarte easy GNOME menu editing tool
software-properties-gtk - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/software-properties-gtk manage the repositories that you install software from (gtk)
ntpdate - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/ntpdate  client for setting system time from NTP servers
gnome-disk-utility - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/gnome-disk-utility manage and configure disk drives and media
ncdu - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/ncdu ncurses disk usage viewer
smplayer - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/smplayer complete front-end for MPlayer and MPlayer2
smplayer-themes - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/smplayer-themes complete front-end for MPlayer - icon themes

sudo apt-get install alacarte software-properties-gtk ntpdate gnome-disk-utility ncdu smplayer smplayer-themes -y


# De/Compression software
sudo apt-get install unace rar unrar zip unzip p7zip p7zip-full p7zip-rar mpack sharutils uudeview arj cabextract -y


# Sync the time
sudo ntpdate -u ntp.ubuntu.com


sudo apt-cache policy smplayer
sudo apt-cache rdepends smplayer
sudo apt-cache search smplayer
sudo apt-show-versions smplayer

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Basic commands - B.1. Shell and Basic Commands p. 479 / short-remedial-course.html - basiccommands - usefullcommands
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Martin Bruchanov - Bourne-Again SHell and Linux CLI bash cheatsheet
http://bruxy.regnet.cz/linux/bash_cheatsheet/bash_cheatsheet.pdf


pwd - print working directory
ls -lha - listing the contents of a directory Human readable
ls -ila - listing the contents of a directory

ls -1 | wc -l - Counting Files in the Current Directory
ls -l | grep -v ^l | wc -l - count only files and NOT include symbolic links

cd - for change directory
cd ~ - will take to root of your users dir
cd # - root of you system
cd Down + TAB - will fill auto-complete the command as "cd Downloads" that will take you to directory Downloads

df -h - report file system disk space usage / -h, --human-readable
man df - manual page for df

su -
sudo -i -
mc - Visual shell for Unix-like systems.
man mc - manual page mc

date "+%A, %d %B %Y %H:%M:%S" - Will display Todays Date + Time - man date

rm - remove files or directories
By default, rm does not remove directories. Use the --recursive (-r or -R) option to remove each listed directory, too, along with all of its contents.


ps -e
ps w
ps aux
ps auxww
kill -9 PID


sudo netstat --program --protocol=inet --tcp --wide --all
sudo netstat --program --protocol=inet --udp --wide --all
sudo netstat -ntl


# Get some useful system info
sudo inxi -Fxz
sudo inxi -r
cat /proc/cpuinfo
sudo dmidecode
sudo biosdecode

# RAM
sudo dmidecode --type 16 --type 17

# Detailed information about specific USB device
lsusb
lsusb -s 1:2 -v



# Things You Can't Do With a GUI: Finding Stuff on Linux
https://www.linux.com/learn/tutorials/458715-things-you-cant-do-with-a-gui-finding-stuff-on-linux

# Linux utility for finding the largest files/directories
http://superuser.com/questions/9847/linux-utility-for-finding-the-largest-files-directories

du -a directoryname | sort -nr | head -n 5
find / -type f -printf '%s %p\n' |sort -nr| head -5

# find the largest 10 files (linux/bash):
find . -type f -print0 | xargs -0 du | sort -n | tail -10 | cut -f2 | xargs -I{} du -sh {}

# find the largest 10 directories:
find . -type d -print0 | xargs -0 du | sort -n | tail -10 | cut -f2 | xargs -I{} du -sh {}



Find recently updated files / 10 largest files - findfiles - filesfind
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# http://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/60605/how-to-know-recently-updated-files
# http://www.cyberciti.biz/faq/how-do-i-find-the-largest-filesdirectories-on-a-linuxunixbsd-filesystem/
find /
find /var/log -cmin -30
find /var/log -size +50k
find /var/log -size -50k
find / -size +100M -cmin -30

find / -name "*.wav"
find / -name index.html

find / -name "*swf"
find / -name "44*.html"
find / -name ""


sudo du -a /var | sort -n -r | head -n 10


update db
locate index.html



du | sort -n
du -hs ~
df -hT | egrep -i "file|^/"
du -a directoryname | sort -nr | head -n 5
ls -lrt | awk '{print $6" "$7" "$9 }' | grep 'May 22'
ls -lrt | grep 'May 22'
find / -type f -printf '%s %p\n' |sort -nr| head -5

df -hT | egrep -i "file|^/"



sudo apt-get install arping -y
sudo arping IPaddress



# WGET
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
man wget

# Download file with wget
wget http://www.sample-videos.com/video/mp4/720/big_buck_bunny_720p_1mb.mp4

# Download file in background
wget  -b http://www.sample-videos.com/video/mp4/720/big_buck_bunny_720p_1mb.mp4

# Resume download if internet connection got interrupted
wget  -c http://www.sample-videos.com/video/mp4/720/big_buck_bunny_720p_1mb.mp4

# Download file from some password protected ftp
wget --ftp-user=<user_name> --ftp-password=<Give_password> Download-url-address

wget --no-check-certificate https://


# CURL
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
man curl

# Download file with curl
curl -o um.mp4 http://www.sample-videos.com/video/mp4/720/big_buck_bunny_720p_1mb.mp4
curl -O http://www.sample-videos.com/video/mp4/720/big_buck_bunny_720p_1mb.mp4

with -o option the file will be saved with that name,
with -O (capital O) option, file will be saved with its original name.




# AXEL
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
man axel

# Download file with Axel
axel http://www.sample-videos.com/video/mp4/720/big_buck_bunny_720p_1mb.mp4



# ARIA2
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
man aria2c


# # Download file with Aria2c
aria2c http://www.sample-videos.com/video/mp4/720/big_buck_bunny_720p_1mb.mp4



# 20 Command Line Tools to Monitor Linux Performance
http://www.tecmint.com/command-line-tools-to-monitor-linux-performance/

http://www.linfo.org/alias.html

cat ~/.bashrc

alias l="ls -lha"
alias p="pwd"







# Open file with specific program
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
whereis xpdf
# navigate to:
/usr/bin/xpdf





# Bits and pieces
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
./ - forget about the PATH, I want you to look only in the current directory.
../ - means in the parent directory.
.. - means one directory lower.
../.. - two directoried lower



------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Disabling the F10 shortcut in Terminal window
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
http://askubuntu.com/questions/37313/how-do-i-deactivate-f1-and-f10-keybindings-in-gnome-terminal

In a gnome-terminal open up Keyboards Shortcuts (Edit ➜ Keyboard Shortcuts) and uncheck
"Enable the menu shortcut key (F10 by default)"






------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    TAR
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
man tar
tar --help

In Windows use http://www.7-zip.org/


# Search for specific files inside tar file for example, look for *.pl (all perl files) inside a detailed table of contents for archive called projects.tar.gz:
tar -tvf projects.tar.bz2 '*.pl'

    t: List the contents of an archive.
    v: Verbosely list files processed (display detailed information).
    z: Filter the archive through gzip so that we can open compressed (decompress) .gz tar file.
    j: Filter archive through bzip2, use to decompress .bz2 files.
    f: Use archive File or device ARCHIVE.





------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Create UNcompressed tar Archive File
tar -cvf donald-$(date +%Y%m%d).tar -P ~/Downloads

tar -cvf donald-16-11-08.tar -P ~/Downloads
tar -cvf donald-16-11-08.tar
    c: creates a new .tar archive file.
    v: verbosely show the .tar file progress.
    f: Use archive File or device ARCHIVE.
    -P: don't strip leading '/'s from file names

# Verify archive files while creation (can not verfify compressed files)!
tar -cvW -f donald-16-11-08.tar -P ~/Downloads
tar -cvW -f donald-$(date +%Y%m%d).tar -P ~/Downloads
tar -cvW -f donald-$(date +%Y%m%d-%H%m).tar -P ~/Documents/


# List the contents of a tar file
tar -tvf donald-16-11-08.tar
    t: List the contents of an archive
    v: verbosely show the .tar file progress.
    f: Use archive file or device ARCHIVE.


# Untar files in specified Directory
tar -xvf donald-16-11-08.tar -C /media/donald/100TB/
    x: extract files from an archive.
    v: verbosely show the .tar file progress.
    f: Use archive File or device ARCHIVE.
    -C: Specified direCtory.


# Extract a single file called /home/donald/scripts/Hilary.sh from donald-16-11-08.tar
tar -xvf donald-16-11-08.tar /home/donald/scripts/Hilary.sh
tar -xvf donald-16-11-08.tar "/home/donald/scripts/Hilary.sh" "/home/donald/scripts/Bill.sh"


# Extract Group of Files using Wildcard
tar -xvf donald-16-11-08.tar --wildcards '*.pdf'


# Add Files / Directories to tar Archive File
tar -rvf donald-16-11-08.tar Hilary150.eml
tar -rvf donald-16-11-08.tar /media/MyStick/files


# Verifying Data as It is Stored
http://ftp.gnu.org/old-gnu/Manuals/tar-1.12/html_node/tar_140.html




# Create compressed gzip *.tar.gz / *.tgz Archive File
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
tar -cvzf Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz -P /home/donald/Pictures
tar -cvzf Pictures-donald-$(date +%Y%m%d).tar.gz  -P /home/donald/Pictures

tar -cvzf Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz /home/donald/Pictures
tar -cvzf Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tgz /home/donald/Pictures
    c: Creates a new .tar archive file.
    v: Verbosely show the .tar file progress.
    z: --gZip, --gunZip --ungZip
    f: Use archive File or device ARCHIVE.
    -P: don't strip leading '/'s from file names


# List the contents of a tar.gz / tgz file
tar -tvf Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz
tar -tvf Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tgz
    t: LisT the contents of an archive.
    v: Verbosely show the .tar file progress.
    f: Use archive File or device ARCHIVE.

# Search the archive.
tar -tvz -f Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz | grep Hilary 239.jpeg


# Test the Archive
gunzip -tv Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz
gunzip -tv Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz


# Uncompress tar.gz Archive File
tar -xvf Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz
tar -xvf Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tgz -C /media/donald/100TB/
    x: eXtract files from an archive.
    v: Verbosely show the .tar file progress.
    f: Use archive File or device ARCHIVE.
    -C: Specified direCtory.

# Extract a single file Hilary.jpeg from Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz archive file
tar -zxvf Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz /home/donald/Pictures/Hilary.jpeg
tar -zxvf Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz "./home/donald/Pictures/Hilary_Email1.jpeg" "./home/donald/Pictures/Hilary_Email15.jpeg"


# Extract Group of Files using Wildcard
tar -zxvf Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz --wildcards '*.gif'




# Calculate and Create checksum file for sha256sum -c backup_20110724.tar.gz
sha256sum Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz > Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz.sha256

# Check this file has been copied, downloaded correctly with:
sha256sum -c Pictures-donald-16-11-08.tar.gz.sha256





# Create highly compressed tar file tar.bz2 / tar.tbz / tar.tb2 Archive File
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
tar -jcvf Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.bz2 -P /home/donald/Documents
tar -jcvf Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.tbz /home/donald/Documents
tar -jcvf Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.tb2 /home/donald/Documents
    j: --bzip2
    c: Creates a new .tar archive file.
    v: Verbosely show the .tar file progress.
    f: Use archive File or device ARCHIVE.
    -P: don't strip leading '/'s from file names


# List the contents of a tar.bz2 file
tar -tvf Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.bz2
tar -tvf Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.tbz
tar -tvf Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.tb2
    t: LisT the contents of an archive.
    v: Verbosely show the .tar file progress.
    f: Use archive File or device ARCHIVE.


# Check
bzip2 -tv Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.bz2
bzip2 -tv Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.tbz
bzip2 -tv Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.tb2


# Uncompress tar.bz2 / tar.tbz / tar.tb2 Archive File
tar -xvf Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.bz2
    x: eXtract files from an archive.
    v: Verbosely show the .tar file progress.
    f: Use archive File or device ARCHIVE.


# Extract a single file called Hilary.txt from the file Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.bz2
tar -jxvf Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.bz2 /home/donald/Documents/Hilary.txt
tar -jxvf Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.bz2 "/home/donald/Documents/Hilary.txt" "/home/donald/Documents/Hilary.txt"


# Extract Group of Files using Wildcard
tar -jxvf Documents-donald-16-11-08.tar.bz2 --wildcards '*.pdf'

mate-keybinding-properties


# for Lock screen
Ctrl+ Alt + L - default I have changed it to Mod4 + L (Win + L)

Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    SUDOers file - visudo
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Root is the super user and has the ability to do anything on a system.
Sudo will allow a user to have administration privileges without logging in as root.


# add to SUDOers file

sudo visudo
########################################################################
#includedir /etc/sudoers.d

donald        ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL
pi                ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL
username    ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL

# User privilege specification
melania        ALL=(ALL:ALL) ALL
########################################################################



Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Configure larger/smaller font on tty console
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sudo dpkg-reconfigure console-setup




Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Localization
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sudo dpkg-reconfigure tzdata
sudo dpkg-reconfigure locales
sudo dpkg-reconfigure keyboard-configuration


locale
locale -a
locale -k date_fmt

mkdir -p $HOME/.locale




Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#     Color Bash Prompt - root
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sudo -i
cd /root
nano .bashrc
########################################################################
PS1='${debian_chroot:+($debian_chroot)}\[\033[01;31m\]\u@\h\[\033[00m\]:\[\033[01;34m\]\w\[\033[00m\]\$ '
########################################################################
. .bashrc
exit





Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Now log out of ROOT account
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
exit

you will see "$" instead of "#" at the end of the line
donaldl@Inspiron2200:~$




Back to Top...

#    Create Folders for downloaded Installation files *.deb / *.tar.* / and GitHub
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Go to root of your home dir - :~$
cd ~/
mkdir ~/Install
mkdir ~/git









Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#     Color Bash Prompt - user
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
$ cd #
nano .bashrc

uncomment #force_color_prompt=yes
. .bashrc

#    Customize nano text editor to display line numbers
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sudo nano /etc/nanorc
########################################################################
uncomment, take out the "#":   
# set const
set const
########################################################################

Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Mosh - (mobile shell)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://mosh.mit.edu
Mosh needs to open a UDP connection.
Mosh will log the user in via SSH, then start a connection on a UDP port between 60000 and 61000.


# To install MOSH
sudo apt-get install mosh -y


mosh donald@192.168.1.2
mosh --ssh="ssh -p 22222" donald@192.168.1.2


See Android Client: JuiceSSH - SSH Client





Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Shellinabox - shell in a box - web ssh - webssh - httpsssh
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/shellinabox

PASTE: Ctl+Shift+V


sudo apt-cache search shellinabox
sudo apt-cache policy shellinabox


# Stable
sudo apt-get install openssl shellinabox

# Unstable - TESTING - don't do it! - DON'T DO IT!
sudo apt-get -t testing install shellinabox


# Re-Install
sudo apt --reinstall install shellinabox



sudo nano /etc/default/shellinabox
########################################################################
# Don't forget to open the port on firewall.
SHELLINABOX_PORT=4200

# Restrict Shellinabox to Localhost Only
SHELLINABOX_ARGS="--no-beep --localhost-only"


#
SHELLINABOX_ARGS="--localhost-only --disable-ssl"

########################################################################



sudo service shellinabox reload
sudo service shellinabox status
sudo systemctl start shellinabox.service
sudo systemctl status shellinabox.service
sudo netstat -nap | grep shellinabox
sudo netstat -plunt

sudo shellinaboxd --help

/usr/bin/shellinaboxd -q --background=/var/run/shellinaboxd.pid -c /var/lib/shellinabox -p 4200 -u shellinabox -g shellinabox --user-css Black on White:+/etc/shellinabox/options-enabled/00+Black on White.css,White On Black:-/etc/shellinabox/options-enabled/00_White On Black.css;Color Terminal:+/etc/shellinabox/options-enabled/01+Color Terminal.css,Monochrome:-/etc/shellinabox/options-enabled/01_Monochrome.css --localhost-only --disable-ssl



https://192.168.1.2:4200/

# Create bash aliases, to make it convenient to start, stop, and reload Shellinabox:
alias shellstart='sudo service shellinabox start'
alias shellstop='sudo service shellinabox stop'
alias shellreload='sudo service shellinabox reload'
alias shellstatus='sudo service shellinabox status'







##NOTES - Create basic auth.
#1 Check that htpasswd exists
which htpasswd
#2 If not install it:
sudo apt-get install apache2-utils
#3 Crete user "donald", the "-c" switch makes that the file is created from scratch; if it didn't exist before, it will be created;
#   if it existed before, it will be overwritten with a new one, and all users from the old file will be lost!
htpasswd -c /var/www/www.example.com/.htpasswd donald
#4 Create new user "melania"
htpasswd /var/www/www.example.com/.htpasswd melania



# Wheezy
sudo invoke-rc.d shellinabox restart



## VPS settings

sudo nano /etc/inittab
########################################################################
1:2345:respawn:/sbin/getty 38400 tty0
########################################################################

# Jessie


# Wheezy
sudo start tty0

#    Install the missing firmware for the Wi-Fi card BCM43xx
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://packages.debian.org/jessie/firmware-b43-installer
firmware-b43-installer

lspci -nn -d 14e4:
sudo apt-cache policy firmware-b43-installer
sudo apt-get install firmware-b43-installer -y


Package: firmware-b43-installer (1:019-2) [contrib]
 * BCM4306/3;
 * BCM4311;
 * BCM4318;
 * BCM4321;
 * BCM4322 (only 14e4:432b);
 * BCM4312 (with Low-Power a.k.a. LP-PHY).

ERROR
########################################################################
[    3.542958] iwlwifi 0000:0c:00.0: firmware: failed to load iwlwifi-6050-5.ucode (-2)
[    3.543025] iwlwifi 0000:0c:00.0: Direct firmware load failed with error -2
[    3.543028] iwlwifi 0000:0c:00.0: Falling back to user helper


########################################################################
ERROR
########################################################################
[    3.743751] iwlwifi 0000:0c:00.0: firmware: failed to load iwlwifi-6050-4.ucode (-2)
[    3.743762] iwlwifi 0000:0c:00.0: Direct firmware load failed with error -2
[    3.743765] iwlwifi 0000:0c:00.0: Falling back to user helper
[    3.774062] iwlwifi 0000:0c:00.0: no suitable firmware found!


https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/firmware-iwlwifi

sudo apt-cache policy firmware-iwlwifi
sudo apt-cache rdepends firmware-iwlwifi
sudo apt-cache search firmware-iwlwifi
sudo apt-cache policy firmware-iwlwifi
sudo apt-show-versions firmware-iwlwifi


donald@LatitudeE4200:~$ sudo apt-cache policy firmware-iwlwifi

#    Binary firmware for various drivers in the Linux kernel / Radeon error
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://packages.debian.org/jessie/firmware-linux-nonfree
firmware-linux-nonfree



beppe@SamsungNP905S3G:~$ dmesg
########################################################################
ERROR
########################################################################
[    3.363233] [drm] radeon kernel modesetting enabled.
[    3.363625] [drm:radeon_pci_probe] *ERROR* radeon kernel modesetting for R600 or later requires firmware-linux-nonfree.



beppe@SamsungNP905S3G:~$ dmesg
########################################################################
ERROR
########################################################################
[    3.037026] AVX version of gcm_enc/dec engaged.
[    3.040022] [drm:radeon_pci_probe] *ERROR* radeon kernel modesetting for R600 or later requires firmware-linux-nonfree.



beppe@SamsungNP905S3G:~$ lspci -v | grep VGA
00:01.0 VGA compatible controller: Advanced Micro Devices, Inc. [AMD/ATI] Temash [Radeon HD 8250/8280G] (prog-if 00 [VGA controller])



https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/firmware-linux-nonfree

sudo apt-cache policy firmware-linux-nonfree
sudo apt-cache rdepends firmware-linux-nonfree
sudo apt-cache search firmware-linux-nonfree
sudo apt-cache policy firmware-linux-nonfree
sudo apt-show-versions firmware-linux-nonfree

sudo apt-get -t jessie-backports install firmware-linux-nonfree

lspci
lspci -nn

#    Broadcom bcma0:0 failed
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

dmesg
########################################################################
ERROR
########################################################################
[   12.179179] Support for cores revisions 0x17 and 0x18 disabled by module param allhwsupport=0. Try b43.allhwsupport=1
[   12.179334] b43: probe of bcma0:0 failed with error -524



lspci -nn -d 14e4:
lspci -vvnn | grep 14e4

donald@P5WS0:/proc$ lspci -vvnn | grep 14e4
02:00.0 Ethernet controller [0200]: Broadcom Corporation NetLink BCM57785 Gigabit Ethernet PCIe [14e4:16b5] (rev 10)
02:00.1 SD Host controller [0805]: Broadcom Corporation BCM57765/57785 SDXC/MMC Card Reader [14e4:16bc] (rev 10) (prog-if 01)
02:00.2 System peripheral [0880]: Broadcom Corporation BCM57765/57785 MS Card Reader [14e4:16be] (rev 10)
02:00.3 System peripheral [0880]: Broadcom Corporation BCM57765/57785 xD-Picture Card Reader [14e4:16bf] (rev 10)
03:00.0 Network controller [0280]: Broadcom Corporation BCM43225 802.11b/g/n [14e4:4357] (rev 01)
    Subsystem: Broadcom Corporation Device [14e4:04da]




WORKING!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
########################################################################
sudo nano /etc/modprobe.d/local-b43.conf
########################################################################
# Activate experimental support for some hardware revisions
options b43 allhwsupport=1
########################################################################


# To make the settings come into effect, turn off networking and unload then reload the module with the commands
sudo rmmod b43
sudo modprobe b43


#NOTES
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=2214110&s
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=2214439



# remove the wrong driver:
sudo apt-get remove --purge bcmwl-kernel-source

sudo apt-cache policy firmware-b43-installer

cat /proc/version
cat /proc/cpuinfo
lsmod | grep -e wl -e b43 -e brcmsmac



donald@P5WS0:/proc$ lsmod | grep -e wl -e b43 -e brcmsmac
brcmsmac              515930  0
cordic                 12352  1 brcmsmac
brcmutil               13093  1 brcmsmac
b43                   378288  0
mac80211              474216  2 b43,brcmsmac
cfg80211              405538  3 b43,brcmsmac,mac80211
ssb                    61008  1 b43
rng_core               12733  1 b43
pcmcia                 49012  2 b43,ssb
bcma                   37206  2 b43,brcmsmac
mmc_core              102374  4 b43,ssb,sdhci,sdhci_pci

https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/firmware-atheros

sudo apt-cache search firmware-atheros
sudo apt-cache policy firmware-atheros
sudo apt-get -t jessie-backports install firmware-atheros
sudo dpkg -V firmware-atheros


sudo update-initramfs -u

 * Realtek RTL8192CU/RTL8188CU TMSC firmware   (rtlwifi/rtl8192cufw_TMSC.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8192CU/RTL8188CU fallback firmware   (rtlwifi/rtl8192cufw.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8192DE firmware (rtlwifi/rtl8192defw.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8192EE wifi firmware (rtlwifi/rtl8192eefw.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8192SE/RTL8191SE firmware, version 4.816.2011   (rtlwifi/rtl8192sefw.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8192SU/RTL8712U firmware (rtlwifi/rtl8712u.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8723AU rev A wifi-with-BT firmware   (rtlwifi/rtl8723aufw_A.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8723AU rev B wifi-with-BT firmware   (rtlwifi/rtl8723aufw_B.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8723AU rev B wifi-only firmware   (rtlwifi/rtl8723aufw_B_NoBT.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8723BE firmware (rtlwifi/rtl8723befw.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8723AE rev B firmware (rtlwifi/rtl8723fw_B.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8723AE rev A firmware (rtlwifi/rtl8723fw.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8821AE firmware (rtlwifi/rtl8821aefw_wowlan.bin)
 * Realtek RTL8821AE firmware (rtlwifi/rtl8821aefw.bin)




Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Duplicate ACPI video bus devices
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
dmesg | grep -i vga


[    5.010149] [Firmware Bug]: Duplicate ACPI video bus devices for the same VGA controller, please try module parameter "video.allow_duplicates=1"if the current driver doesn't work.



sudo nano /etc/modprobe.d/video.conf
########################################################################
video.allow_duplicates=1
########################################################################

#    NVIDIA Proprietary Driver - NvidiaGraphicsDrivers
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://wiki.debian.org/NvidiaGraphicsDrivers#Identification


lspci -nn | grep VGA
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
donald@PrecisionM6600:~$ lspci -nn | grep VGA
01:00.0 VGA compatible controller [0300]: NVIDIA Corporation GF104GLM [Quadro 4000M] [10de:0e3b] (rev a1)




nvidia-detect - https://packages.debian.org/jessie-backports/nvidia-detect NVIDIA GPU detection utility
sudo apt-get -t jessie-backports install nvidia-detect




nvidia-detect
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
donald@PrecisionM6600:~$ nvidia-detect
Detected NVIDIA GPUs:
01:00.0 VGA compatible controller [0300]: NVIDIA Corporation GF104GLM [Quadro 4000M] [10de:0e3b] (rev a1)

Checking card:  NVIDIA Corporation GF104GLM [Quadro 4000M] (rev a1)
Your card is supported by the default drivers and legacy driver series 304.
It is recommended to install the
    nvidia-driver
package.


https://wiki.debian.org/NvidiaGraphicsDrivers#jessie-304xx


http://us.download.nvidia.com/XFree86/Linux-x86_64/304.125/README/supportedchips.html
Quadro 4000M     0x0E3B     C


# Unix Driver Archive
http://www.nvidia.com/object/unix.html


# Linux x64 (AMD64/EM64T) Display Driver
http://www.nvidia.com/Download/driverResults.aspx/95154/en-us
Version:     304.131
Release Date:     2015.11.16
Operating System:     Linux 64-bit
Language:     English (US)
File Size:     66.2 MB




1# Add "contrib" and "non-free" components to /etc/apt/sources.list, for example:

sudo nano /etc/apt/sources.list
########################################################################
# Debian 8 "Jessie"
deb http://httpredir.debian.org/debian/ jessie main contrib non-free

### So it looks like this:
# Base repository Debian 8 "Jessie"
deb http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian/ jessie main non-free contrib
deb-src http://ftp.uk.debian.org/debian/ jessie main non-free contrib
########################################################################




2# Update the list of available packages.
sudo aptitude update



3# Install the appropriate linux-headers and kernel module packages:
# This will also install the recommended nvidia-legacy-304xx-driver package. DKMS will build the nvidia module for your system.
https://packages.debian.org/jessie/nvidia-legacy-304xx-driver

sudo aptitude -r install linux-headers-$(uname -r|sed 's,[^-]*-[^-]*-,,') nvidia-legacy-304xx-kernel-dkms



 ┌────────────────────────┤ Configuring xserver-xorg-video-nvidia-legacy-304xx ├────────────────────────┐                                                                                   
 │                                                                                                      │                                                                                   
 │ Manual configuration required to enable NVIDIA driver                                                │                                                                                   
 │                                                                                                      │                                                                                   
 │ The NVIDIA driver is not yet configured; it needs to be enabled in xorg.conf before it can be used.  │                                                                                   
 │                                                                                                      │                                                                                   
 │ Please see the package documentation for instructions.                                               │                                                                                   
 │                                                                                                      │                                                                                   
 │                                                <Ok>                                                  │ 





4# Create an Xorg server configuration file.
https://wiki.debian.org/NvidiaGraphicsDrivers#configure


nvidia-xconfig (340.46-1) - https://packages.debian.org/jessie/nvidia-xconfig X configuration tool for non-free NVIDIA drivers
sudo apt-get install nvidia-xconfig



5# Run it with sudo. It will automatically generate a Xorg configuration file at /etc/X11/xorg.conf.
sudo nvidia-xconfig

donald@PrecisionM6600:~$ sudo nvidia-xconfig

WARNING: Unable to locate/open X configuration file.

New X configuration file written to '/etc/X11/xorg.conf'



6# Restart your system to enable the nouveau blacklist.
sudo reboot





sudo dpkg-reconfigure xserver-xorg
sudo dpkg-reconfigure x11-common



0# Re-install XServer / Xorg
# Xorg -configure
# cp /root/xorg.conf.new /etc/X11/xorg.conf
startx

PRETTY_NAME="Debian GNU/Linux 8 (jessie)"
NAME="Debian GNU/Linux"
VERSION_ID="8"
VERSION="8 (jessie)"
ID=debian
HOME_URL="http://www.debian.org/"
SUPPORT_URL="http://www.debian.org/support"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.debian.org/"

sudo deluser -remove-home melania

#    LightDM - display users on login
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://wiki.debian.org/LightDM
http://www.webupd8.org/2014/08/lightdm-how-to-disable-user-list-or.html



# Viewing current configuration:
/usr/sbin/lightdm --show-config



sudo mkdir -p /etc/lightdm/lightdm.conf.d
sudo nano  /etc/lightdm/lightdm.conf.d/50-my-custom-config.conf
########################################################################
[SeatDefaults]
greeter-hide-users=false
greeter-show-manual-login=true
allow-guest=false
########################################################################


# To change the current default Display Manager:
sudo dpkg-reconfigure lightdm


#NOTES
sudo cat /etc/lightdm/lightdm.conf
sudo nano /etc/lightdm/lightdm.conf

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Securing SSHD - RSA ECDSA ED25519
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sudo cp /etc/ssh/sshd_config /etc/ssh/sshd_config.OLD
sudo nano /etc/ssh/sshd_config
########################################################################
# Change the port number
Port 110

# Allow user melania to connect from IPv6
AllowUsers melania@2001:8a0:11da::/48
AllowUsers melania@80.180.90.160/26

# Deny login with "root" login
# DELETE # to enable
PermitRootLogin without-password
########################################################################


# Restart SSH / SSHD
sudo service ssh restart
sudo service sshd restart




sudo nano /etc/hosts.deny
########################################################################
ALL: PARANOID

# or
SSHD: all
nginx: ALL
vsftpd : 192.168.1. , .abc.com
in.telnetd : 192.168.5.6 : allow
sshd ,ftpd : ALL
ALL: ALL
########################################################################



sudo nano /etc/hosts.allow
########################################################################
SSHD: 80.180.90.160/26                                             # NOTES
SSHD: 2001:8a0:11da::/48                                          # NOTES
########################################################################

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    SSH config stanza - sshshort - sshquick - sshql
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


cd ~
nano ~/.ssh/config
nano ~/.ssh/config
nano ~/.ssh/config
########################################################################
# Amazon AWS EC2
Host ec2
    HostName    50.100.70.100
    Port 22
    IdentityFile /media/SDHC_UHS-I/Ubuntu_Server_1204_LTS_PV_EU_Ireland_eu-west-1b.pem
    User ubuntu


########################################################################
# Amazon AWS EC2 - LocalForward
Host ec2l
    HostName    50.100.70.100
    Port 22
    IdentityFile /media/SDHC_UHS-I/Ubuntu_Server_1204_LTS_PV_EU_Ireland_eu-west-1b.pem
    LocalForward 9906 127.0.0.1:3306
    User ubuntu


########################################################################
# Amazon AWS EC2 - RemoteForward
Host ec2r
    HostName    50.100.70.100
    Port 22
    IdentityFile /media/SDHC_UHS-I/Ubuntu_Server_1204_LTS_PV_EU_Ireland_eu-west-1b.pem
    RemoteForward 19999 127.0.0.1:18383
    User ubuntu







Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Reverse SSH Tunnel - Reverese_SSH
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

TWO PC's via SERVER vps.xxx.us
########################################################################
On PC1: RaspberryPi3
ssh -R 19999:localhost:29999 admin@vps.xxx.us -p 39999
########################################################################
On PC2: Linux PC
ssh vps # IF you have setup stanza
ssh admin@vps.xxx.us -p 39999

ssh -D 4096 pi@localhost -p 19999 # Doesn't work if connection via SERVER
ssh pi@localhost -p 19999
########################################################################
39999 - SSH port of SERVER vps.xxx.us
29999 - SSH port of PC1: RaspberryPi3
19999 - SSH port on SERVER forwarded to PC1





Back to Top...

ssh -D 4096 donald@192.168.1.2 -p 22222


TunnelSwitch in Chrome Web Store
https://github.com/oylbin/tunnel-switch

Socks Proxy Add-on for Firefox
https://github.com/p1rox/socksproxy-firefox-addon

SOCKS 5
Port 4096




------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    FTP - File Transfer Protocol
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File_Transfer_Protocol



------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    FTPS - FTP over SSL also known as FTPES, FTP-SSL, S-FTP
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FTPS



------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    SFTP - Simple File Transfer Protocol
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File_Transfer_Protocol#Simple_File_Transfer_Protocol

https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc913

Simple File Transfer Protocol (the first protocol abbreviated SFTP), as defined by RFC 913,
was proposed as an (unsecured) file transfer protocol with a level of complexity intermediate between TFTP and FTP.

port 115

It has a command set of 11 commands and support three types of data transmission: ASCII, binary and continuous.




------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    SFTP - SSH File Transfer Protocol
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SSH_File_Transfer_Protocol

Chroot SFTP
http://www.thegeekstuff.com/2012/03/chroot-sftp-setup/


sftp user@domain_or_IP
sftp -oPort=ss pi@xxx.us:/mnt/array1/web/htdocs


sftp -oPort=22568 ec2:/var/www/html/





Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    SCP - Secure copy - securecopy
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secure_copy

scp -P 22222 ~/.ssh/id_ecdsa.pub pi@192.168.1.222:.ssh/authorized_keys



Upload file "NRT.odt" in my current dir to server "pi@xxx.us" and directory "/var/www/japan/"
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
scp -P 20202 /home/donald/Documents/NRT.odt pi@xxx.us:/var/www/japan/

from location"/home/donald/Documents/NRT.odt"
to "pi@xxx.us:/var/www/japan/"
ssh port on remote server "20202"




Download file "NRT.odt" from the server "pi@xxx.us" and directory "/var/www/japan/" to my current dir.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
scp -P 20202 pi@xxx.us:/var/www/japan/NRT.odt .

from location "pi@xxx.us:/var/www/japan/NRT.odt"
to absolute path "." at the end
ssh port on remote server "20202"










Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    SSHFS (SSH File System) - see Essential software first - MATE for installation of sshfs
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SSHFS


https://blog.mehl.mx/2014/mounting-a-sftp-storage-in-gnu-linux/
http://blog.max-mehl.com/2014/mounting-a-sftp-storage-in-gnu-linux/


# Make a DIR where you want the files to be mapped
mkdir ~/MOI
# Map the Filesystem
sshfs -p 22 root@192.168.90.185:/mnt/ ~/MOI/ -o follow_symlinks

-p 22 = SSH port on the target server
root@192.168.90.185 = login details
:/mnt/ = folder that you want to be mapped
~/MOI/ = folder on you PC where you want /mnt/ to be mapped
-o follow_symlinks = follow symlinks it here are any in your /mnt/ @ root@192.168.90.185


# Unmount the folder
fusermount -u ~/MOI/





# Config stanza for MOI
nano ~/.ssh/config
###############################################################
# MOI - DVB-S2 Streaming Box - IPv4
Host moi
    HostName 192.168.90.185
    Port 22
    User root
###############################################################


# To mount the /mnt directory on the sever in ~/MOI directory on my PC
sshfs moi:/mnt/ ~/MOI -o follow_symlinks


# Unmount the folder
fusermount -u ~/MOI/
