#    HTTP over SSL/TLS - HTTPS / 443 - Lets Encrypt /  Security Research Group (ISRG) - letsencrypt
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://letsencrypt.org/certificates/
https://letsencrypt.org/upcoming-features/
https://www.identrust.com/certificates/trustid/root-download-x3.html


#A Lets Encrypt with ACME.sh
#B Lets Encrypt with letsencrypt/git/python


# ACME.sh
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://github.com/Neilpang/acme.sh
https://github.com/Neilpang/acme.sh/wiki


# ACME.sh: snadná cesta k certifikátu od Let's Encrypt
http://www.root.cz/clanky/acme-sh-snadna-cesta-k-certifikatu-od-let-s-encrypt/



#1 To download / install
cd ~/git
git clone https://github.com/Neilpang/acme.sh.git
cd ./acme.sh
./acme.sh --install

#or
curl https://get.acme.sh | sh
#or
wget -O -  https://get.acme.sh | sh



#2 Check what's installed and cron is running
ls -lha ~/.acme.sh/
ps aux | grep crond
crontab -l

ls -lha /etc/cron.hourly/
ls -lha /etc/cron.daily/
ls -lha /etc/cron.weekly/
ls -lha /etc/cron.monthly/



#3 Create "letsencrypt" user




#4 Adjust NginX settings
sudo nano /etc/nginx/conf.d/default.conf
########################################################################
location ^~ /.well-known/ {
    root /home/letsencrypt/webroot/;
}
########################################################################



#5 Generate certificate
.acme.sh/acme.sh --issue -d example.com  -w /home/letsencrypt/webroot/ -d www.example.com -d blog.example.com -d forum.example.com --reloadcmd "sudo /etc/init.d/nginx reload"



#6 Allow user "letsencryp" to reload nginx
sudo visudo
########################################################################
letsencrypt     ALL = NOPASSWD:/etc/init.d/nginx reload
########################################################################



#7
ls -ila ~/.acme.sh/example.com



#8 NginX config
########################################################################
ssl_certificate /home/letsencrypt/.acme.sh/example.com/fullchain.cer;
ssl_certificate_key /home/letsencrypt/.acme.sh/example.com/example.com.key;
########################################################################



#9 Revoking certificate
.acme.sh/acme.sh --revoke -d example.com




#10 Get pkcs12(pfx) format:
acme.sh  --toPkcs  -d <domain>  [--password pfx-password]












# Let's Encrypt – nahoďte šifrování na webu (Petr Krčmář)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DmxoItxQ4Dc

ACME - Automated Certificate Management Environment = JSON on HTTPS
Ident Trust = DST Root CA X3

# Restrictions
- Only (DV) Domain Validation cert
- No wildcard cert (*.debian.club)
- 100 Alternative Name
- Valid only for 90 days
- 5 SLD requests per week



# Clients
- (Python) letsencrypt
- (Python) letsencrypt-nosudo
- (Python) letsencrypt_simpleclient
- (Python) acme-tiny
- (Python) simp_le
- ......PHP, Go, Ruby, .NET
- (HTTP) https://gethttpsforfree.com/


TLSA in DNS - reuse key
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
http://www.internetsociety.org/deploy360/resources/dnssec-registrars/

# Dependecies:
sudo apt-get install python-unbound python-m2crypto python-argparse python-ipaddr

cd ~/git
git clone https://github.com/pieterlexis/swede.git
cd swede
./swede create --output rfc --usage 3 --selector 1 www.debian.club


:~/git/swede$ ./swede --help
usage: swede [-h] [--insecure] [--resolvconf /PATH/TO/RESOLV.CONF]
             [--trust-anchor-file /PATH/TO/TRUST-ANCHOR.KEY] [-v] [--quiet]
             {verify,create} ... hostname

Create and verify DANE records.

positional arguments:
  hostname

optional arguments:
  -h, --help            show this help message and exit
  --insecure            Allow use of non-dnssec secured answers
  --resolvconf /PATH/TO/RESOLV.CONF
                        Use a recursive resolver from resolv.conf
  --trust-anchor-file /PATH/TO/TRUST-ANCHOR.KEY
                        Path to a file containing additional trust anchor(s)
                        for validation
  -v, --version         show version and exit
  --quiet, -q           Only print the result of the creation / validation

Functions:
  {verify,create}       Available functions, see swede function -h for
                        function-specific help
    verify              Verify a TLSA record, exit 0 when all TLSA records are
                        matched, exit 2 when a record does not match the
                        received certificate, exit 1 on error.
    create              Create a TLSA record

This tool has a few limitations



# Generate DNS TLSA resource record from a certificate and given parameters.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://www.huque.com/bin/gen_tlsa
_443._tcp.level.club. IN TLSA 3 1 1 8fa6ae8a6885b82f57a3f3b3d93a775db7533b9f88bca9e297d60d4ef774f818


# Check
dig _443._tcp.www.debian.club TLSA










# Petr Krčmář: TLS certifikát pod mikroskopem
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
/www.youtube.com/watch?v=47sj8xdjAsQ

no SNI (Server Name Indication)- XP SP3 not working/
RFC 7258 - Pervasive Monitoring Is an Attack

SSL3 = TLS1
cca 60 Certificate Authority in the world


cd /etc/letsencrypt/live/debian.club/
less *.crt/pem
cp *.crt/pem *.txt
nano *.txt Delete -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- / -----END CERTIFICATE-----
base64 -d *.txt |less

#Display the certificate PEM /DER (binary) base64
openssl s_client -showcerts -connect debian.club:443 -servername debian.club < /dev/null | openssl x509 -outform PEM
openssl s_client -showcerts -connect debian.club:443 -servername debian.club < /dev/null | openssl x509 -outform DER

#Download the cert
openssl s_client -showcerts -connect debian.club:443 -servername debian.club < /dev/null | openssl x509 -outform PEM > debian.club.crt.pem
openssl s_client -showcerts -connect debian.club:443 -servername debian.club < /dev/null | openssl x509 -outform DER > debian.club.cer.der


# Viewing certificates
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
1# In web browser


2# from shell on local pc
openssl x509 -in cert.pem -text -noout
openssl x509 -in certificate.crt -text -noout

echo | openssl s_client -connect google.com:443 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -issuer
echo | openssl s_client -connect google.com:443 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -subject
echo | openssl s_client -connect google.com:443 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -dates
echo | openssl s_client -connect google.com:443 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -hash
echo | openssl s_client -connect google.com:443 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -fingerprint
echo | openssl s_client -connect google.com:443 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -issuer -subject -dates
echo | openssl s_client -connect google.com:443 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -text
echo | openssl s_client -connect debian.club:443 -servername debian.club 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -text



3# Using GUI client on local pc/local cert
gcr-viewer --help-all
gcr-viewer cert.pem


CN: debian.club
# or
CN: info@debian.club


# Viewing certificates
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Data:
Version number:  version 3 (0x2) - RFC2459
Serial number: must be uniqe to that authority
Issuer:  C=countryName / O =organizationName / OU=organizatinUnitName / ST=stateOrProvinceName / CN=commonName
Validity: GMT/Zulu included seconds
CN:

X509v3 extensions: FC5280:
1. key usage, 2. basic constraints, 3. key identifiers, , 4. certificate policies


#1
X509v3 Key Usage: critical
    Digital Signature, Key Encipherment

X509v3 Extended Key Usage:
    TLS Web Server Authentication, TLS Web Client Authentication

#2
X509v3 Basic Constraints: critical
    CA:FALSE

#3
X509v3 Subject Key Identifier:
    68:C8:CC:9C:F3:78:DC:09:FF:8C:40:28:FA:D0:CD:8F:F2:97:3B:C7

X509v3 Authority Key Identifier:
    keyid:A8:4A:6A:63:04:7D:DD:BA:E6:D1:39:B7:A6:45:65:EF:F3:A8:EC:A1

Authority Information Access:
    OCSP - URI:http://ocsp.int-x3.letsencrypt.org/
    CA Issuers - URI:http://cert.int-x3.letsencrypt.org/

X509v3 Subject Alternative Name:
    DNS:debian.club, DNS:www.debian.club

#4   
X509v3 Certificate Policies:
    Policy: 2.23.140.1.2.1
    Policy: 1.3.6.1.4.1.44947.1.1.1
    CPS: http://cps.letsencrypt.org
    User Notice:
    Explicit Text: This Certificate may only be relied upon by Relying Parties and only in accordance with the Certificate Policy found at https://letsencrypt.org/repository/

2.23.140.1.2.1 Domain Validation (DV)
2.23.140.1.2.2 Organization Validation (OV)
OID - Extended Validation (EV)



# Revoking certificates
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#1 - CRL - Certificate Revocation List - Need to maintain database of revocated certs, large in size ..
wget http://crl.identrust.com/DSTROOTCAX3CRL.crl
openssl crl -inform DER -text -noout -in DSTROOTCAX3CRL.crl


#2 - OCSP -  Online Certificate Status Protocol - NOT IMPLEMENTED IN CHROME
OCSP stapling RFC6961 -  addressing privacy



# OCSP query
openssl s_client -connect www.debian.club:443 -servername debian.club -showcerts 2>&1 < /dev/null
openssl s_client -connect www.debian.club:443 -servername debian.club -showcerts -status < /dev/null
openssl s_client -connect www.debian.club:443 -servername debian.club -status < /dev/null

cd /etc/letsencrypt/live/debian.club/
openssl x509 -in cert.pem -noout -ocsp_uri
openssl x509 -in debian.club.pem -noout -ocsp_uri
echo | openssl s_client -connect debian.club:443 -servername debian.club 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -ocsp_uri


cd /etc/letsencrypt/live/debian.club/
openssl ocsp -no_nonce -issuer chain.pem -verify_other chain.pem -cert cert.pem -url http://ocsp.int-x3.letsencrypt.org/ -header "HOST" ocsp.int-x3.letsencrypt.org
openssl ocsp -no_nonce -issuer chain.pem -verify_other chain.pem -cert cert.pem -url http://ocsp.int-x3.letsencrypt.org/ -header "HOST" ocsp.int-x3.letsencrypt.org -text
- good
- revoked
- unknown




Cross Signing = Let's Encrypt X3 - DSTG X3 Ident Trust

Common Name (CN)
Organization (O) - In address bar NAME






https://www.phpbb.com/
https://forums.gentoo.org/

#    nginx.org_GPG key expiration & update

https://forum.nginx.org/read.php?2,267655,267655

wget https://nginx.org/keys/nginx_signing.key && apt-key add ../nginx_signing.key
# or
cd ~/Install
wget https://nginx.org/keys/nginx_signing.key && sudo apt-key add nginx_signing.key



ERROR:
W: An error occurred during the signature verification. The repository is not updated and the previous index files will be used. GPG error: http://nginx.org jessie Release: The following signatures were invalid: KEYEXPIRED 1471427554

W: Failed to fetch http://nginx.org/packages/debian/dists/jessie/Release 

W: Some index files failed to download. They have been ignored, or old ones used instead.



sudo apt-key list
sudo apt-key list | grep “expired:”
sudo apt-key adv --recv-keys --keyserver keys.gnupg.net 7BD9BF62

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    APT
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------


AptCdrom
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/AptCdrom



1. Uncoment all sources apart of CD-ROM

2.
sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get dist-upgrade

3. test: 
sudo apt-cdrom --no-act add

4. if everything is OK: 
sudo apt-cdrom add

5.
sudo apt-cdrom ident

6.
sudo apt-cdrom -d "your-cdrom-mount-point" -r


add is used to add a new disc to the source list. It will unmount the CDROM device, prompt for a disk to be inserted and then procceed to scan it and copy the index files.
If the disc does not have a proper .disk/ directory you will be prompted for a descriptive title. APT uses a CDROM ID to track which disc is currently in the drive
and maintains a database of these IDs in /var/lib/apt/cdroms.list

ident is a debugging tool to report the identity of the current disc as well as the stored file name.

-d or --cdrom : MountPoint (specify the location to mount the cdrom). This mount point must be listed in /etc/fstab and properly configured.

-r or --rename : rename a disc; change the label of a disk or override the disks given label. This option will cause apt-cdrom to prompt for a new label.

-n, --just-print, --recon or --no-act: no Changes; Do not change the sources.list file and do not write index files. Everything is still checked however.


7.
sudo apt-get -f install

8.
sudo dpkg --configure -a









------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Migrate MySQL to another server
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://errorin10.wordpress.com/2016/03/18/migrate-mysql-to-another-server/



# Backup - The basic call to backup a MySQL looks like this:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
(no space between -p and the password!)

mysqldump -u root -p[root_password] [database_name] > dumpfilename.sql

mysqldump -u root -pSTRONGROOTPASSWORD ––all-databases > backup.sql




# Copy using SCP
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
scp backup.sql user@host:/home/user

scp backup.sql user@host:/home/user
scp backup.sql donald@vps.myhosting.com:/home/user
scp -P 2200 Whos-saving-whom.mkv donald@vps.myhosting.com:/home/donald
scp -P 2200 MakeMKV_log.txt donald@vps.myhosting.com:/mnt/NAS/test


http://www.teraterm.net/manual/en/macro/command/scpsend.html
connect '192.168.3.2:22 /ssh /2 /auth=password /user=hoge /passwd=fuga'
wait '$'
scpsend 'C:\usr\cvs\doc\en\teraterm.chm'
scpsend 'C:\usr\cvs\doc\en\teraterm.chm' 'tmp/foo.chm'




# Import - The basic call to import looks like this:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
mysql -u root -p[root_password] [database_name] < backup.sql
mysql -u root -pSTRONGROOTPASSWORD < backup.sql

Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Installing Raspbian OS onto the SD/MicroSD card
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Check for new version of RasbianOS powering your RaspberryPi (current Release date:2016-05-27):
# https://www.raspberrypi.org/downloads/raspbian/
# https://downloads.raspberrypi.org/raspbian/release_notes.txt

# https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/installation/installing-images/linux.md
# http://elinux.org/RPi_Easy_SD_Card_Setup
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Download the latest Rasbian Jessie Lite Image (Minimal image based on Debian Jessie, no Desktop / GUI / X11)
wget http://director.downloads.raspberrypi.org/raspbian_lite/images/raspbian_lite-2016-05-31/2016-05-27-raspbian-jessie-lite.zip
https://downloads.raspberrypi.org/raspbian_latest.torrent
https://downloads.raspberrypi.org/raspbian_lite_latest.torrent


# Check SHA-1: 03b6ea33efc3bb4d475f528421d554fc1ef91944
sha1sum 2016-05-27-raspbian-jessie-lite.zip
sha1sum -c  2016-05-27-raspbian-jessie-lite.zip.SHA1SUM


# Unzip the img file
uzip 2016-05-27-raspbian-jessie-lite.zip


# CHECK - CHECK - CHECK where is your microSD card mounted:
sudo blkid
df -h


# Unmaunt MicroSD Card, if it is mounted
umount /dev/sdc1
umount /dev/mmcblk0p1


# Install PV so we can see the progress bar
sudo apt-get install pv


# Write the *.img file to your MicroSD card
# CECK AGAIN, is "of=/dev/sdc" CORRECT DRIVE?
sudo dd bs=4M if=2016-05-27-raspbian-jessie-lite.img | pv | sudo dd of=/dev/sdc
sudo sync


# SSH into the RPi
ssh pi@raspberrypi
raspberry


# Configure: Expand filesystem, Hostname, GPU split, ......
sudo raspi-config


# Install "rpi-update" so we can get up to date version of firmware "Only in Lite version"
https://www.raspberrypi.org/forums/viewtopic.php?f=29&t=144087
sudo apt-get install rpi-update


#
sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get upgrade && sudo apt-get dist-upgrade && sudo rpi-update
sudo apt-get install -fy
sudo reboot


# Install basic tools
sudo apt-get install htop mc iftop arp-scan -y


# Check the serial number of you RPi
cat /proc/cpuinfo





https://community.openenergymonitor.org/t/pi-hardware-detection/727





# Boost USB Current in Raspberry Pi 2 and B+ "max_usb_current=1"
http://www.modmypi.com/blog/boost-usb-current

sudo nano /boot/config.txt
########################################################################
# Enable 1.2A (1200mA) SHARED instead of 0.6A (600mA) SHARED
max_usb_current=1
########################################################################

# This is same as above command "max_usb_current=1"
safe_mode_gpio=4

# Troubleshooting
lsusb -v 2>/dev/null | grep -e 'MaxPower' -e 'Bus [0-9]'
lsusb -v | grep MaxPower







W: GPG error: http://ftp.uk.debian.org jessie-backports InRelease: The following signatures couldn't be verified because the public key is not available: NO_PUBKEY 8B48AD6246925553 NO_PUBKEY 7638D0442B90D010
sudo apt-key adv --keyserver pgp.mit.edu --recv-keys 8B48AD6246925553
sudo apt-key adv --keyserver pgp.mit.edu --recv-keys 7638D0442B90D010





# tvheadend as tvheadend client
https://tvheadend.org/boards/4/topics/20555









# Raspberry Pi Webcam
http://www.dronkert.net/rpi/webcam.html




Back to Top...
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Now install the RTL-2832U USB dongle driver source and compile
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Install dependencies
sudo apt-get install git git-core cmake libusb-1.0-0-dev build-essential
sudo apt-get install pkg-config

# Clone the files
git clone git://git.osmocom.org/rtl-sdr.git

#
cd rtl-sdr/

#
mkdir build

#
cd build/

# In order to be able to use the dongle as a non-root user, you may install the appropriate udev rules file by calling cmake with -DINSTALL_UDEV_RULES=ON argument in the above build steps.
sudo cmake ../ -DINSTALL_UDEV_RULES=ON -DDETACH_KERNEL_DRIVER=ON

#
sudo make    

#
sudo make install

#
sudo ldconfig

#
cd ..

#
#sudo cp ./rtl-sdr/rtl-sdr.rules /etc/udev/rules.d/
sudo cp rtl-sdr.rules /etc/udev/rules.d/

#
sudo reboot

  0:  Realtek, RTL2838UHIDIR, SN: 00000001

Using device 0: Generic RTL2832U OEM
Detached kernel driver
Found Rafael Micro R820T tuner
Supported gain values (29): 0.0 0.9 1.4 2.7 3.7 7.7 8.7 12.5 14.4 15.7 16.6 19.7 20.7 22.9 25.4 28.0 29.7 32.8 33.8 36.4 37.2 38.6 40.2 42.1 43.4 43.9 44.5 48.0 49.6
[R82XX] PLL not locked!
Sampling at 2048000 S/s.
No E4000 tuner found, aborting.
Reattached kernel driver

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Blaclist driver from loading:
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

# Stop the driver from loading:
sudo nano /etc/modprobe.d/rtl-sdr-blacklist.conf
########################################################################
# This system has librtlsdr0 installed in order to
# use digital video broadcast receivers as generic
# software defined radios.
blacklist dvb_usb_rtl28xxu
blacklist e4000
blacklist rtl2832
########################################################################

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# Using Kalibrate
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
http://www.satsignal.eu/raspberry-pi/acars-decoder.html

cd ~/git
sudo apt-get install libtool autoconf automake libfftw3-dev
git clone https://github.com/asdil12/kalibrate-rtl.git
cd kalibrate-rtl
git checkout arm_memory        # Essential for the Raspberry Pi
./bootstrap
./configure
make
sudo make install


kal -s GSM900 -d 0 -g 40
kal -c 112 -d 0 -g 40


# Wait 1 or 2 minutes, GSM-900 will apear and then few minutes later channels:
kal -s GSM900 -d 0 -g 40
-s GSM900 Scanning for GSM-900 base stations.
-d 0
-g 40 = gain: 40.0 dB


# Pick two or more with the highest powers, do multiple runs to calculate the frequency offsets, and take the integer average:
kal -c <channel> -d 0 -g 40




# Whole sequence
sudo /etc/init.d/dump1090-mutability stop
kal -s GSM900 -d 0 -g 40
kal -c 210 -d 0 -g 40
sudo nano /etc/default/dump1090-mutability
sudo /etc/init.d/dump1090-mutability start







pi@raspberrypi ~/kal/kalibrate-rtl $ kal -s GSM850 -d 0 -g 40
Found 1 device(s):
  0:  Generic RTL2832U OEM

Using device 0: Generic RTL2832U OEM
Found Rafael Micro R820T tuner
Exact sample rate is: 270833.002142 Hz
Setting gain: 40.0 dB
kal: Scanning for GSM-850 base stations.
GSM-850:
    chan: 151 (873.8MHz + 24.340kHz)    power: 1530919.13
    chan: 159 (875.4MHz - 11.167kHz)    power: 1083769.76
    chan: 160 (875.6MHz + 34.720kHz)    power: 1135433.62
    chan: 161 (875.8MHz - 11.089kHz)    power: 1812354.13
    chan: 169 (877.4MHz - 30.211kHz)    power: 3042227.58
    chan: 200 (883.6MHz - 16.646kHz)    power: 589171.86
    chan: 210 (885.6MHz - 31.580kHz)    power: 4065945.25
    chan: 214 (886.4MHz - 31.540kHz)    power: 398330.73




pi@raspberrypi ~/kal/kalibrate-rtl $ kal -c 210 -d 0 -g 40
Found 1 device(s):
  0:  Generic RTL2832U OEM

Using device 0: Generic RTL2832U OEM
Found Rafael Micro R820T tuner
Exact sample rate is: 270833.002142 Hz

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    ModeSMixer2
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
http://xdeco.org/?page_id=48


# Download
http://xdeco.org/?page_id=30



# modesmixer2 and MLAT data on port30004
http://discussions.flightaware.com/post186705.html#p186705


sudo piaware-config -show
##################
mlatResultsFormat {beast,connect,localhost:30104 ext_basestation,listen,30106

# To avoid upsetting the working Piaware setup, I tried adding a new listen port with Beast format and restarting:
sudo piaware-config -mlatResultsFormat "beast,connect,localhost:30104 ext_basestation,listen,30106 beast,listen,31003"
sudo service piaware restart


# Now there should be MLAT data in Beast format on port 31003. Combining the ADSB traffic on port 30005 gives all the data from Piaware:
modesmixer2 --inConnect <Pi IP>:31003 --inConnect <Pi IP>:30005 --web <port>
--inServerId <Port:Label>

Windows modesdeco2_windows_20150815.zip https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7NYXizl0U6iMmNjdXIyY1haTWc
Ubuntu 14.04 32 bit: modesdeco2_i386_20150815.tgz https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7NYXizl0U6iNVRfa1B1cFlsQzQ
Ubuntu 14.04 64 bit: modesdeco2_x86_64_20150815.tgz https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7NYXizl0U6iNnE0d19rcV9tUFk
Raspberry Pi 2: modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815.tgz https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7NYXizl0U6iRS1yQXc1R2REODg
Odroid C: modesdeco2_odroid_C_20150628.tgz https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7NYXizl0U6iRnpzY2NhX0RHTlU
Odroid U3: modesdeco2_odroid_U3_20150628.tgz https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7NYXizl0U6iZGNkVjJNNnJKUHc
Odroid XU: modesdeco2_odroid_XU_20150720.tgz https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7NYXizl0U6iWFJTeG5fNnJMb2s
Freescale i.MX6Q CUBOX-i4Pro: modesdeco2_cubox-i4pro_20150628.tgz https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B7NYXizl0U6iaVJUX3hqUUg0ekU



########################################################################
When you are on the page "Map":
In most Windows and Linux browsers: Hold down Ctrl and press F5.
In Apple Safari: Hold down ⇧ Shift and click the Reload toolbar button.

Ctrl+Shift+Del = Clear Browsing Data
########################################################################







The "A"l etter  means ADS-B (selection criteria is coordinates and DF17 messages)
and the letter "S" corresponds to Mode S.


SORTOUT!!!!

cd modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815

# Stop Dump1090-mutability
sudo /etc/init.d/dump1090-mutability stop

FlightRoute
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://groups.yahoo.com/neo/groups/PP-logs-and-routes/files

flightroute.sqb for Plane Plotter - four-letter ICAO airport codes. Cleaned of reported errors, but some routes may have IATA format names.
This file must be renamed unzipped and "flightroute.sqb".

# Get from PS folder on debian.club!
wget http://debian.club/ps/flightroute-2015-09-20-0400.icao.zip
unzip flightroute-2015-09-20-0400.icao.zip
wget http://debian.club/ps/flightroute-2015-09-20-0400.iata.zip
unzip flightroute-2015-09-20-0400.iata.zip

mkdir pictures
wget http://debian.club/ps/flags/MUSTANG51.Flags.27-02-2013.4987.zip
unzip MUSTANG51.Flags.27-02-2013.4987.zip -d pictures

wget http://woodair.net/SBS/Download/CDF.zip

wget http://woodair.net/SBS/Download/FLAG_SET_4.zip
wget http://woodair.net/SBS/Download/FLAG_SET_5.zip

SQB Manipulation
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

# SQLiteStudio
http://sqlitestudio.pl/ database manager
http://radarspotting.com/forum/index.php/topic,2978.msg24471.html#msg24471


wget http://sqlitestudio.pl/files/sqlitestudio3/complete/linux64/sqlitestudio-3.0.7.tar.xz
tar -xJf sqlitestudio-3.0.7.tar.xz
cd SQLiteStudio/
./sqlitestudio
./sqlitestudiocli



# My ADS-B Log is Now Online
http://sonicgoose.com/my-ads-b-log-is-now-online/

# Today’s Flights — How To Extract Data from BaseStation.sqb
http://sonicgoose.com/todays-flights-how-to-extract-data-from-basestation-sqb/


# Command Line Shell For SQLite
# http://www.sqlite.org/cli.html
sudo apt-get install sqlite3
sqlite3 BaseStation.test.sqb ".schema" > basestation.sqb.table_layout.txt
cat basestation.sqb.table_layout.txt


sqlite3 test.db
.help
create table tbl1(one varchar(10), two smallint);
create table tbl1(one varchar(10), two smallint);
insert into tbl1 values('hello!',10);
insert into tbl1 values('goodbye', 20);
select * from tbl1;
hello!|10
goodbye|20











# Run the file (don't forget to set your location LAT/LON)
########################################################################
cd modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815
./modesdeco2 --device-list
########################################################################
cd modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815
./modesdeco2 --rbs --gain 49.6 --freq-correction 62 --web 1090 --location 51.123456:-0.7654321 --avr 30031 --avrmlat 33003 --beast 31001 --msg 30003 --sbs10001 10001 --db BaseStation.sqb --frdb flightroute-2015-09-20-0400.icao.sqb --silhouettes silhouettes --pictures pictures
########################################################################
--metric
cd modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815
./modesdeco2 --rbs --gain 49.6 --freq-correction 62 --web 1090 --location 51.123456:-0.7654321 --beast 31001 --msg 30003 --sbs10001 10001 --avr 30031 --avrmlat 33003 --metric --db BaseStation.sqb --frdb flightroute-2015-09-20-0400.icao.sqb --silhouettes silhouettes --pictures pictures
########################################################################
--device-index 1
cd modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815
./modesdeco2 --device-index 1 --rbs --gain 49.6 --freq-correction 62 --web 1090 --location 51.123456:-0.7654321 --beast 31001 --msg 30003 --sbs10001 10001 --avr 30031 --avrmlat 33003 --metric --db BaseStation.sqb --frdb flightroute-2015-09-20-0400.icao.sqb --silhouettes silhouettes --pictures pictures

########################################################################
# will go to background
cd modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815

nohup ./modesdeco2 --rbs --gain 49.6 --freq-correction 62 --web 1090 --location 51.123456:-0.7654321 --beast 31001 --msg 30003 --sbs10001 10001 --avr 30031 --avrmlat 33003 --db BaseStation.sqb --frdb flightroute-2015-09-06-1645.iata.sqb --silhouettes ~/modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815/silhouettes --pictures ~/modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815/pictures &
########################################################################
--device-index


cd modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815
./modesdeco2 --device-list
./modesdeco2 --device-serial 00000001 --web 1090



pi@RaspberryPi2 ~/modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815 $ ./modesdeco2 --device-list
2015-09-22 16:30:53.809  INFO     ModeSDeco2 v.20150815

Available RTL Devices:
 0 mnf: Realtek prod: RTL2832U serial: 00000508
 1 mnf: Realtek prod: RTL2838UHIDIR serial: 00000001

No Available AirSpy devices.



cd modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815
./modesdeco2 --rbs --gain 49.6 --web 1090 --location 51.123456:-0.7654321 --beast 31001 --sbs10001 30003 --db BaseStation.sqb --frdb flightroute-2015-09-06-1645.icao.sqb --silhouettes silhouettes
nohup ./modesdeco2 --rbs --gain 49.6 --web 1090 --locat51.123456:-0.7654321ion  --beast 31001 --sbs10001 30003 --db BaseStation.sqb --silhouettes silhouettes &


./modesdeco2 --gain 49.6 --freq-correction 62 --location 32.471:104.998 --web 8088 --db /path/to/basestation.sqb --frdb /path/to/flightroute.sqb --silhouettes /path/to/silhouettes --pictures /path/to/pictures --beast 10003
/home/pi/modesdeco2/modesdeco2 --rbs --gain 49.6 --web 8081 --beast 31001 --sbs10001 30003 --db /home/pi/modesdeco2/BaseStation.sqb --silhouettes /home/pi/modesdeco2/silhouettes &


./modesdeco2 --help
./modesdeco2 --verbose
./modesdeco2 --device-list
cat modesdeco2.readme

# Example for RTL:
./modesdeco2 --gain 49.6 --freq-correction 62 --location 32.471:104.998 --web 8088 --db ~/data/basestation.sqb --frdb ~/data/flightroute.sqb --silhouettes ~/data/silhouettes --pictures ~/data/pictures --beast 10003 --msg 30003 --sbs10001 10001




http://xdeco.org/?page_id=39
########################################################################
--verbose                 Verbose mode

--rbs                     Enabes RBS (Radar Beacon System) decoding for receive Mode A/C and Mode S messages simultaneously. By default is off.

--gain 49.6                Sets a fixed value of gain for the receiving chip (R820T, E4000 …) in dB. By default is Auto.

--freq-correction 62     Sets an adjustment by entering the ppm (parts per million) offset value. The crystal of oscillator acting as the master clock for the dongle is an unadjusted 28.8 MHz device.
                        Since the frequency error is completely linear over the tuning range of the device, an error correction in ppm (parts per million) can be used to adjust and correct the device
                        at the software side of operation. By default is 0.

--filter-nocountry        Disable ICAO Country filter (default: on) - blocks messages from such unallocated addresses, because more often they are formed under influence of interference.
                       
                       
           


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--avr 30031                 Enables a TCP server, that listen incoming connections on port for output data in AVR format which is a ASCII hexdump of the raw frame contents.
                                    It can be text messages: 56 Bit Mode-S frames, as *02E99619FACDAE; 112 Bit Mode-S frames, as *8D3C5EE69901BD9540078D37335F; Mode-A/C frames, as
                                    *7700 (Mode-A/C frame values are octal). By default is off.
                           
*5F4CA64000ECB3;
*3520;
*1720;
*5D4CA5DA428AD4;
*1720;
*1720;
*1720;
*5F4CA64000ECB3;
*A8000610C4640170A80000E09EC1;
*A0001218B6B00030A6000039CCF5;
*A0000BB88013812F6004B071AE57;
*5D49528E0A70B9;
*20000E969383A7;


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--avrmlat 33003               Enables a TCP server, that listen incoming connections on port for output data in AVR format which is a ASCII hexdump of the raw frame contents with 6 Byte time stamp.
                                        It can be text messages: 56 Bit Mode-S frames, as @016CE3671C7402E99619FACDAE; 112 Bit Mode-S frames, as @016CE3671AA88D3C5EE69901BD9540078D37335F; Mode-A/C frames,
                                        as @016CE3671C747700 (Mode-A/C frame values are octal). By default is off.
                           
@000122E637345446;
@000122E8C82E7120;
@000122E8C8347120;
@000122E8DD8802E6109ECA6D2B;
@000122E9561202E6109ECA6D2B;
@000122E9DE9E5D400A3283557B;
@000122EE1ACA5D4067EF7C1797;
@000122EE1DD65D40051727143D;
@000122EE525CA0000C9410010680B60000B31C32;
@000122EF118A02C1883D0D5312;
@000122F0962E2000183851E4B4;
@000122F09B26A0000C9410010680B60000B31C33;
@000122F29FE65D4067EF7C1797;
@000122F430785D4067EF7C1797;


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--beast 31001                 Enables a TCP server, that listen incoming connections on port for output data in BEAST format which is a binary hexdump of the raw frame contents.
                                       It can be binery messages: 6 Byte MLAT time stamp, 1 Byte signal level, 2 Byte Mode-AC or 7 Byte Mode-S short frame, or 14 Byte Mode-S long frame. By default is off.

>�€õ��ÃK2�'*¢XV �Ÿþz1�'*¢ æBe 1�'*£*C"R1�'*£†^e 1�'*¥HüV2�'*¥mV     � º­Ž2�'*¥˜Ö    ]L¢’kYc1�'*¥¡jQ"R1�'*¦ Ee 2�'*¦~ Á‹¸ëF3�'*§Îò    46“`=%„{ÜY^é¥1�'*§ÿp\"R2�'*¨&ŽáŽº”ê¬1�'*¨âªS@A2�'*©&¨ ]L¢’kYc3�'*©/ ¨�
]DÙ‘:}Ù1�'*¿w  2�'*¿Åh#]@
®®ÛÙ2�'*ÀTº€]L¥ÚBŠÆ1�'*ÀV2�'*À¸2áŽº”ê¬1�'*Àê¨ 1�'*ÁUÊV2�'*Áª`(�‰–ùg2�'*Â.Øwæîu˜3�'*Ãd>ÿ¨� ÎYï?÷û¾­ƒ3�'*Ãvþÿ¨� ýù‘!ÌöA;2�'*ÃÐòáŽº”ê¬2�'*Ä¦
]@
®®ÛÙ2�'*Åä4ÿ]45Qß¾?3�'*Ç �’•€�0Ì��H³q2�'*È6


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--msg 30003                 Enables a TCP server, that listen incoming connections on port for output data in eight different MSG type messages, which is a text strings. Each message type contains
                                    up to 22 different fields, as MSG,3,0,0,780B45,0,2014/11/09,15:45:26.981,2014/11/09,15:45:26.981,,37000,,,57.591568,71.852818,,,,,,0. Often this format are called as MSG30003,
                                    because TCP port 30003 has become the de-facto standard for transmission of MSG messages. By default is off.
                                    Kinetic MSG

MSG,5,0,0,400E8C,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.358,2015/09/21,18:30:51.358,,9775,,,,,,,,,0,0
MSG,5,0,0,400E8C,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.362,2015/09/21,18:30:51.362,,9775,,,,,,,,,0,0
MSG,5,0,0,4CA5DA,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.366,2015/09/21,18:30:51.366,,28000,,,,,,,,,0,0
MSG,8,0,0,4CA5DA,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.367,2015/09/21,18:30:51.367,,,,,,,,,,,,0
MSG,5,0,0,343551,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.369,2015/09/21,18:30:51.369,,10000,,,,,,,,,0,0
MSG,4,0,0,400DAE,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.370,2015/09/21,18:30:51.370,,,406.5,148.9,,,1984,,,,,0
MSG,5,0,0,4CA97E,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.372,2015/09/21,18:30:51.372,,18000,,,,,,,,,0,0
MSG,5,0,0,400DAE,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.373,2015/09/21,18:30:51.373,,20725,,,,,,,,,0,0
MSG,8,0,0,400E8C,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.375,2015/09/21,18:30:51.375,,,,,,,,,,,,0
MSG,8,0,0,400E8C,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.380,2015/09/21,18:30:51.380,,,,,,,,,,,,0
MSG,8,0,0,4CA640,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.381,2015/09/21,18:30:51.381,,,,,,,,,,,,0
MSG,8,0,0,4CA5DA,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.382,2015/09/21,18:30:51.382,,,,,,,,,,,,0
MSG,5,0,0,400DAE,0,2015/09/21,18:30:51.383,2015/09/21,18:30:51.383,,20725,,,,,,,,,0,0


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--sbs10001 10001            Enables a TCP server, that emulates SBS-1/3 receiver from Kinetic Avionics and allows to connect BaseStation program directly. By default is off.

NO OUTPUT



# http://radarspotting.com/forum/index.php/topic,2978.msg25295.html#msg25295
However, it should be noted that the format from Kinetic is obsolete and unable to transfer full range of modern data which we are now able to decode from a DF transponder messages.
I think for data transfer it is better to use any of the RAW formats (BEAST or AVR), if only not to work with legacy programs or if for the task just enough to use a limited set of data.


http://radarspotting.com/forum/index.php/topic,2978.msg25567.html#msg25567
As I think, today universal RAW is BEAST or AVR. (Or subtype AVRMLAT = AVR + time stamp for MLAT, if you necessary MLAT function.) The BEAST format contains the MLAT time stamp always.
They are identical in their ability to transfer all current data.

The difference between them is only that the BEAST is a binary format and its messages cannot be readable in text console. BEAST is most compact in size for network transmission.
Whereas AVR is ASCII format and each message can be viewed as separate human-readable string of text. Additionally BEAST has capability of transferring received signal level.



ps -e
ps w
ps aux
kill -9




pi@RaspberryPi2 ~/modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815 $ ./modesdeco2 --help
ModeSDeco2 v.20150815
Program options:
  -h [ --help ]            This help message
  --device-list            List available devices
  --device-index arg       Select RTL device (default: 0)
  --device-serial arg      Select RTL device by serial number
  --gain arg               Set Gain in RTL Receiver chip, dB (default: auto)
  --agc                    Enable Automatic Gain Control in RTL2832 chip (default: off)
  --freq-correction arg    Set RTL frequency correction, ppm (default: 0)
 
  --airspy                 Select AirSpy device
  --airspy-sn arg          Select AirSpy device by serial number
  --airspy-lna arg         Set LNA gain in AirSpy Receiver chip (default: 15)
  --airspy-mixer arg       Set Mixer gain in AirSpy Receiver chip (default: 15)
  --airspy-if arg          Set IF gain in AirSpy Receiver chip (default: 8)
  --airspy-sr arg          Set AirSpy sample rate (default: max available) Example: 4, 6, 10
  --input-file arg         Set input filename with I/Q signals Format: type:filename (type: rtl,airspy10,airspy6)
 
  --rbs                    Enable RBS decoding (default: off)
  --beast arg              Enable BEAST output listen port (default: off)
  --avr arg                Enable AVR output listen port (default: off)
  --avrmlat arg            Enable AVR MLAT output listen port (default: off)
  --avrmlatas arg          Enable AVR MLAT AirSpy output listen port (default: off)
  --sbs10001 arg           Enable SBS-3 output listen port (default: off)
  --msg arg                Enable MSG output listen port (default: off)
  --web arg                Enable Web Server on port (default: off)
  --web-auth arg           Enable web auth username:password (default: off)
  --disable-web-log        Disable Web Log (default: on)
 
  --silhouettes arg        Set Silhouettes directory
  --pictures arg           Set Aircraft Pictures directory
  --db arg                 Set BaseStation DB Filename
  --frdb arg               Set FlightRoute DB Filename
  --location arg           Receiver location Lat:Lon Example: 36.27:-15.89
  --verbose                Verbose mode (default: off)
  --localtime              Local Time in MSG format output (default: UTC)
  --filter-expire arg      Filter record expire time, sec (default: 20)
  --filter-count arg       Filter record min count (default: 6)
  --filter-time arg        filter record min time, sec (default: 60)
  --filter-nocountry       Disable ICAO Country check filter (default: on)
  --filter-ic              Enable Interrogator Code suppression filter (default: off)
  --flight-expire-time arg Flight expire time, sec (default: 3600)
  --nmea arg               Enable GPS Emulation. Format: ICAO:Port:BaudRate
  --nmea-logfile arg       Set GPS Emulator logfile
  --metric                 Switch to metric system of distance measurement (default: imperial)

  --outConnectUdp <arg>       Use it if you need output data to send over UDP (as client) to a remote UDP server.
  --inServerUdp <arg>       The <arg> is one - UDP Port.       


As argument to specify the format (only one) of output data sent (beast,avr,avrmlat,msg,sbs30006,sbs10001,fatsv), IP address of the remote UDP server and number of Port on which it listens UDP.



Programs modesdeco2/modesmixer2 can works with a database in sqlite3 format.
The database structure may be identical to basestation.sqb used in BaseStation.exe, VirtualRadarServer (plugin), PlanePlotter and others.

sudo apt-get install sqlite3
sqlite3 BaseStation.test.sqb ".schema" > basestation.sqb.table_layout.txt
cat basestation.sqb.table_layout.txt



# on Laptop/PC
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
mkdir modesdeco2; cd modesdeco2

./modesdeco2 --rbs --gain 49.6 --freq-correction 62 --web 1090 --location 51.123456:-0.7654321 --beast 31001 --msg 30003 --sbs10001 10001 --avr 30031 --avrmlat 33003 --db BaseStation.sqb --frdb flightroute-2015-09-20-0400.iata.sqb --silhouettes silhouettes
--pictures ~/modesdeco2_rpi2_20150815/pictures


https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/METAR
METAR for airport: (enter 4-letter airport identifier code)
EGLL / LHR
EGLK / BBS

#    TVHeadEnd
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://tvheadend.org/


UK IP Crime Report 2016 Reveals IPTV/Kodi Piracy as Growing Threat
https://torrentfreak.com/uk-ip-crime-report-2016-reveals-iptvkodi-piracy-as-growing-threat-160929/


# JFrog Bintray install
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://bintray.com/tvheadend/deb/tvheadend
https://dl.bintray.com/tvheadend/deb/dists/jessie/




# Jessie!!!!!
* release - for the latest official release = binary-amd64/binary-armhf/binary-i386
* stable - for nightly build of latest release branch (will pick up fixes quicker than release) = binary-amd64/binary-i386
* unstable - for nightly build of master branch (don't use on production systems) = binary-amd64/binary-armel/binary-armhf/binary-i386
* obsolete - historic 3.4 build to keep older users happy = binary-amd64/binary-armhf/binary-i386




#1 Install APT HTTPS, ad PGP key
------------------------------------------------------------------------
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install apt-transport-https -y
sudo apt-key adv --keyserver hkp://keyserver.ubuntu.com:80 --recv-keys 379CE192D401AB61






#2 Add
------------------------------------------------------------------------
sudo nano /etc/apt/sources.list
########################################################################
# TVHeadEnd
#deb https://dl.bintray.com/tvheadend/deb {distribution} {components}
deb https://dl.bintray.com/tvheadend/deb jessie release
########################################################################
# Or
echo "deb https://dl.bintray.com/tvheadend/deb {distribution} {components}" | sudo tee -a /etc/apt/sources.list



#3 Update
------------------------------------------------------------------------
sudo apt-get update




#4 Install TVHeadEnd - Build: 4.0.8~jessie / Sunday, 06 March 2016
------------------------------------------------------------------------
sudo apt-get install tvheadend -y


 ┌────────────────────────────────────────────┤ Configuring tvheadend ├──────────────────────────┐ 
 │ Tvheadend is accessed via a world reachable web interface (assuming your host is reachable from the internet).   │ 
 │ To protect from malicious use you must create an initial account to be able to login to Tvheadend. This account   │ 
 │ can not be changed nor deleted from within Tvheadend itself. If you want to change the superuser account you    │ 
 │ need to reconfigure the Tvheadend package.                                                                                                              │ 
 │                                                                                                                                                                                      │ 
 │ Choose a username for Tvheadend administrator.                                                                                                      │ 
 │                                                                                                                                                                                      │ 
 │ _______________________________________________________________________________________________________ │ 
 │                                                                                                                                                                                      │ 
 │                                 <Ok>                                     <Cancel>                                                                                     │ 
 │                                                                                                                                                                                      │ 
 └───────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ 
                                                                                                                      
                                         ┌────┤ Configuring tvheadend ├────┐                                         
                                         │                                                                                                     
                                         │                                                                                                     
                                         │ Administrator password.                                                            
                                         │                                 
                                         │ ________________________________                                          
                                         │                                                                           
                                         │      <Ok>          <Cancel>                                               
                                         │                                                                          
                                         └──────────────────────────────┘                                         
                                                                                                                      

    ┌─────────────────────────────────────────┤ Configuring tvheadend ├──────────────────────────┐    
    │                                                                                                           
    │ After installation Tvheadend can be accessed via HTTP on port 9981. From this machine you can point your
    │ web-browser to http://localhost:9981/                                                                     
    │                                                                                                           
    │                                                   <Ok>                                                       
    │                                                                                                               
    └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘    


# Remove
sudo apt-get --purge remove tvheadend

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Upgrading OpenWRT CHAOS CALMER (15.05, r46767) to CHAOS CALMER (15.05.1, r48532) on Linksys E3000
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://openwrt.org/

Chaos Calmer 15.05.1
Released: Mon, 16 Mar 2016
https://downloads.openwrt.org/chaos_calmer/15.05.1/brcm47xx/generic/




#1
Download the new image/md5sums to TMP folder
cd /tmp
wget http://downloads.openwrt.org/chaos_calmer/15.05.1/brcm47xx/generic/openwrt-15.05.1-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin
wget http://downloads.openwrt.org/chaos_calmer/15.05.1/brcm47xx/generic/md5sums
wget http://downloads.openwrt.org/chaos_calmer/15.05.1/brcm47xx/generic/sha256sums


#2
Check the checksums of the downloaded file
md5sum -c md5sums 2> /dev/null | grep openwrt-15.05.1-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin
# CHAOS CALMER (15.05, r46767) does not support sha256sum
sha256sum -c sha256sums 2> /dev/null | grep openwrt-15.05.1-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin

# Output you should see:
openwrt-15.05-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin: OK


#3
Now upgrading with more verbose output (no need to convert to TRX format anymore :)
sysupgrade -v /tmp/openwrt-15.05.1-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin

# Output you should see:
Found CyberTAN image with device pattern: 61XN
Found a valid TRX version 1
Saving config files...
etc/config/dhcp
etc/config/dropbear
etc/config/firewall
etc/config/luci
etc/config/network
etc/config/rpcd
etc/config/system
etc/config/ucitrack
etc/config/uhttpd
etc/config/wireless
etc/dnsmasq.conf
etc/dropbear/authorized_keys
etc/dropbear/dropbear_dss_host_key
etc/dropbear/dropbear_rsa_host_key
etc/firewall.user
etc/group
etc/hosts
etc/inittab
etc/opkg.conf
etc/passwd
etc/ppp/chap-secrets
etc/ppp/filter
etc/ppp/options
etc/profile
etc/protocols
etc/rc.local
etc/services
etc/shadow
etc/shells
etc/sysctl.conf
etc/sysupgrade.conf
Sending TERM to remaining processes ... dnsmasq ubusd askfirst logd rpcd netifd odhcpd uhttpd ntpd
Sending KILL to remaining processes ... askfirst
Switching to ramdisk...
Performing system upgrade...
Unlocking firmware ...

Writing from <stdin> to firmware ...    
Appending jffs2 data from /tmp/sysupgrade.tgz to firmware...
Writing from <stdin> to firmware ...  [w]118912+0 records in
118912+0 records out
   
Upgrade completed
Rebooting system...




#4
After ssh log-in you should see this:

BusyBox v1.23.2 (2016-03-01 08:50:20 CET) built-in shell (ash)

  _______                     ________        __
 |       |.-----.-----.-----.|  |  |  |.----.|  |_
 |   -   ||  _  |  -__|     ||  |  |  ||   _||   _|
 |_______||   __|_____|__|__||________||__|  |____|
          |__| W I R E L E S S   F R E E D O M
 -----------------------------------------------------
 CHAOS CALMER (15.05.1, r48532)
 -----------------------------------------------------
  * 1 1/2 oz Gin            Shake with a glassful
  * 1/4 oz Triple Sec       of broken ice and pour
  * 3/4 oz Lime Juice       unstrained into a goblet.
  * 1 1/2 oz Orange Juice
  * 1 tsp. Grenadine Syrup
 -----------------------------------------------------
root@OpenWrt:~#


#5
root@OpenWrt:~# cat /proc/version
Linux version 3.18.23 (buildbot@builder1) (gcc version 4.8.3 (OpenWrt/Linaro GCC 4.8-2014.04 r48532) ) #1 Tue Mar 1 09:17:16 CET 2016






Install Midnight Commander
------------------------------------------------------------------------
opkg update
opkg install mc



Install Nano
------------------------------------------------------------------------
opkg update
opkg install nano



For additional security, you may disable Luci webserver altogether and start the service via ssh when needed.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
/etc/init.d/uhttpd disable
/etc/init.d/uhttpd stop
/etc/init.d/uhttpd start






------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    Upgrading OpenWRT BARRIER BREAKER (14.07, r42625) to CHAOS CALMER (15.05, r46767) on Linksys E3000
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

BusyBox v1.22.1 (2014-09-21 02:05:47 CEST) built-in shell (ash)
Enter 'help' for a list of built-in commands.

  _______                     ________        __
 |       |.-----.-----.-----.|  |  |  |.----.|  |_
 |   -   ||  _  |  -__|     ||  |  |  ||   _||   _|
 |_______||   __|_____|__|__||________||__|  |____|
          |__| W I R E L E S S   F R E E D O M
 -----------------------------------------------------
 BARRIER BREAKER (14.07, r42625)
 -----------------------------------------------------
  * 1/2 oz Galliano         Pour all ingredients into
  * 4 oz cold Coffee        an irish coffee mug filled
  * 1 1/2 oz Dark Rum       with crushed ice. Stir.
  * 2 tsp. Creme de Cacao
 -----------------------------------------------------

#1
Download the new image/md5sums to TMP folder
cd /tmp
wget http://downloads.openwrt.org/chaos_calmer/15.05/brcm47xx/generic/openwrt-15.05-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin
wget http://downloads.openwrt.org/chaos_calmer/15.05/brcm47xx/generic/md5sums


#2
Check the checksums of the downloaded file
md5sum -c md5sums 2> /dev/null | grep openwrt-15.05-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin

# Output you should see:
openwrt-15.05-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin: OK


#3
Now upgrading with more verbose output (need to convert to TRX format :)
sysupgrade -v /tmp/openwrt-15.05-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin

# Output you should see:
Invalid image type. Please use only .trx files
Image check 'platform_check_image' failed.


#4
Convert to TRX format
dd if=openwrt-15.05-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin bs=32 skip=1 of=openwrt-15.05-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin.trx

# Output you should see:
118912+0 records in
118912+0 records out


#5
Check the files starts with HDR0
hexdump -C openwrt-15.05-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin.trx | head

# Output you should see:
00000000  48 44 52 30 00 10 3a 00  57 80 e4 39 00 00 01 00  |HDR0..:.W..9....|
00000010  1c 00 00 00 0c 09 00 00  00 04 11 00 1f 8b 08 00  |................|
00000020  00 00 00 00 02 03 8d 57  5d 68 54 e9 19 7e ce 37  |.......W]hT..~.7|
00000030  67 32 27 31 d9 7e 99 8c  76 74 83 9c cf 39 99 0c  |g2'1.~..vt...9..|
00000040  89 17 a3 88 b5 30 a5 a7  33 b3 bb 81 ee c5 ac ca  |.....0..3.......|
00000050  d6 82 c8 10 d3 ea c5 16  b2 6d a1 bd 90 e5 10 63  |.........m.....c|
00000060  1b 4a f0 4c c5 42 7a 53  86 98 b8 16 86 8c 46 6d  |.J.L.BzS......Fm|
00000070  f7 42 d7 90 dd fe 5c ee  b6 50 7a 51 4a aa c2 7a  |.B....\..PzQJ..z|
00000080  99 42 a9 76 4b 7b fa bc  67 26 35 6b 73 d1 c0 f0  |.B.vK{..g&5ks...|
00000090  cd 7c 7f cf f3 3e ef cf  f7 e6 a3 e8 7e 4e 63 a9  |.|...>......~Nc.|


#6
Upgrading:
sysupgrade -v /tmp/openwrt-15.05-brcm47xx-generic-linksys-e3000-v1-squashfs.bin.trx

# Output you should see:
Saving config files...
etc/config/dhcp
etc/config/dropbear
etc/config/firewall
etc/config/luci
etc/config/network
etc/config/rpcd
etc/config/system
etc/config/ucitrack
etc/config/uhttpd
etc/config/wireless
etc/dropbear/authorized_keys
etc/dropbear/dropbear_dss_host_key
etc/dropbear/dropbear_rsa_host_key
etc/group
etc/hosts
etc/inittab
etc/opkg.conf
etc/passwd
etc/profile
etc/rc.local
etc/shadow
etc/shells
etc/sysctl.conf
Sending TERM to remaining processes ... ubusd askfirst logd netifd odhcpd uhttpd ntpd dnsmasq
channel 4: open failed: connect failed:
Sending KILL to remaining processes ... askfirst
Switching to ramdisk...
Performing system upgrade...
Unlocking firmware ...

Writing from to firmware ...  [w] - [e]
  
Appending jffs2 data from /tmp/sysupgrade.tgz to firmware...
Writing from to firmware ...  [w]channel 3: open failed: connect failed:
  
Upgrade completed
Rebooting system...



#7
After ssh log-in you should see this:

BusyBox v1.23.2 (2015-07-24 14:37:28 CEST) built-in shell (ash)

  _______                     ________        __
 |       |.-----.-----.-----.|  |  |  |.----.|  |_
 |   -   ||  _  |  -__|     ||  |  |  ||   _||   _|
 |_______||   __|_____|__|__||________||__|  |____|
          |__| W I R E L E S S   F R E E D O M
 -----------------------------------------------------
 CHAOS CALMER (15.05, r46767)
 -----------------------------------------------------
  * 1 1/2 oz Gin            Shake with a glassful
  * 1/4 oz Triple Sec       of broken ice and pour
  * 3/4 oz Lime Juice       unstrained into a goblet.
  * 1 1/2 oz Orange Juice
  * 1 tsp. Grenadine Syrup
 -----------------------------------------------------

SERIES=LinkStation
PRODUCTNAME=LS-WSGL/R1(SUJIN)
VERSION=0.16
SUBVERSION=FLASH 0.00
PRODUCTID=0x00003002
BUILDDATE=2008/11/10 13:33:18
BOOTVER=1.23

PRODUCTNAME=LS-WSXL(KINMEI)
VERSION=0.16
SUBVERSION=FLASH 0.00
PRODUCTID=0x00003007
BUILDDATE=2013/05/16 13:38:04
BOOTVER=0.21

SERIES=LinkStation
PRODUCTNAME=LS-CHL(YURYAKU)
VERSION=0.16
SUBVERSION=FLASH 0.00
PRODUCTID=0x00000012
BUILDDATE=2013/07/09 14:39:57
BOOTVER=0.22




root@LS-CHL8B3:/mnt/disk1/share/wget# wget https://xxx.us/FILES/.Donald/NEW.tar.gz
https://xxx.us/FILES/.Donald/NEW.tar.gz: HTTPS support not compiled in.

http://buffalo.nas-central.org/wiki/Ipkg_on_the_Linkstation_(for_end-users)
ipkg update
ipkg list
ipkg list|grep wget
ipkg list|grep wget-ssl
ipkg remove wget
ipkg install wget-ssl

Compatible series:
LS-XHL, LS-CHL, LS-WXL, LS-WSXL,
LS-SL, LS-AVL, LS-VL, LS-WVL,
LS-QVL, LS-XL, LS-YL, LS-WXBL

Install ipkg on Buffalo Linkstation 421e

Login to the NAS via SSH as root
Run the following:
wget http://ipkg.nslu2-linux.org/feeds/optware/cs05q3armel/cross/stable/teraprov2-bootstrap_1.2-7_arm.xsh
sh teraprov2-bootstrap_1.2-7_arm.xsh
Now, run 'ipkg update' to update the list of packages available
Run 'ipkg list' to list the packages available to install

#    BackUp
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/BackupYourSystem/TAR

$ tar -cpvf SVP.1121.BackUp.home_20160406.tar.gz /home/donald/
# tar -cpvf SVP1121.BackUp.var_20160406.tar.gz /var/
# tar -cpvf SVP1121.BackUp.etc_20160406.tar.gz /etc/


     -c: Create archive
      -p will preserve the original file permissions
       -v: Verbose i.e display progress while creating archive
        -f: Archive File name



# Compiling
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/InstallingSoftware

make distclean

http://users.telenet.be/mydotcom/howto/linux/package02.htm

# Installing packages from source code with checkinstall
http://www.debian-administration.org/article/147/Installing_packages_from_source_code_with_checkinstall

# Uninstall files installed from a source code tar ball on Linux or Unix
http://www.cyberciti.biz/tips/uninstall-files-installed-from-a-source-code-tar-ball.html
CheckInstall keeps track of all the files created or
modified by your installation script (“make install”
“make install_modules”, “setup”, etc), builds a
standard binary package and installs it in your
system giving you the ability to uninstall it with your
distribution’s standard package management utilities.



find /* | grep -v -e ^/proc/ -e ^/tmp/ -e ^/dev/ -e ^/home/ > packgetlist.b4
find /* > packgetlist.b4
...................
./configure --option=1 --foo=bar etc
make
make install
..................
find /* | grep -v -e ^/proc/ -e ^/tmp/ -e ^/dev/ -e ^/home/ > packagelist.after
find /* > packagelist.after

diff packagelist.b4 packagelist.after > package.uninstall.list

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# NFC - (Near Field Communication)
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
https://wiki.debian.org/NFC
https://packages.debian.org/source/jessie/libnfc

libnfc -

libnfc-bin libnfc-examples libnfc5

https://packages.debian.org/source/sid/mrtdreader
mrtdreader
https://github.com/rubund/mrtdreader



# Public platform independent Near Field Communication (NFC) library
http://nfc-tools.org/index.php?title=Libnfc


# Make sure you have required compilation dependencies:
sudo apt-get install libusb-dev
sudo apt-get install libusb-0.1-4

# Download and extract libnfc archive:
git clone https://github.com/nfc-tools/libnfc.git
cd libnfc
git checkout libnfc-1.7.1
git clean -d -f -x
#rm ../libnfc*.deb
git remote|grep -q anonscm||git remote add anonscm git://anonscm.debian.org/collab-maint/libnfc.git
git fetch anonscm
git checkout remotes/anonscm/master debian
git reset
dpkg-buildpackage -uc -us -b


# Install libnfc into your system
sudo dpkg -i ../libnfc*.deb



# Plug in NFC device, place a tag on it and test your installation:
nfc-list


# Crete configuration file
sudo nano /etc/nfc/libnfc.conf


# An entry in /etc/nfc/devices.d/ to describe the hardware
sudo nano /etc/nfc/devices.d/


https://lwn.net/Articles/645843/
http://nfc-tools.org/index.php?title=Pam_nfc



http://docs.esupport.sony.com/pc/SVP1121_1321_series/EN/contents/TP0000059716.html
http://docs.esupport.sony.com/pc/SVP1121_1321_series/EN/contents/TP0000053405.html
http://www.sony-asia.com/support/download/564557
12. Intel® NFC Driver: INDNFC-00295907-0082.EXE





https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.nxp.taginfolite
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.nxp.nfc.tagwriter
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.samsung.tectiles2
https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=at.mroland.android.apps.nfctaginfo
NTAG21x
NTAG213/215/216: NFC Forum Type 2 Tag compliant IC with 144/504/888 bytes user memory















------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
# GPS with F3607gw / 1546:01a7 U-Blox AG
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
sudo apt-get install gpsd screen gpsd-clients python-gps pps-tools

https://packages.debian.org/jessie/pps-tools
sudo apt-get install pps-tools



donald@LatitudeE4200:~$ lsusb
Bus 008 Device 003: ID 413c:8184 Dell Computer Corp. F3607gw v2 Mobile Broadband Module
Bus 001 Device 005: ID 1546:01a7 U-Blox AG



sudo lsusb -d 413c:8184 -v | grep GPS
sudo lsusb -d 413c:8184 -v | grep -B3  iInterface

dmesg | grep -i ACM


# enable GPS with updates at 2 second intervals
echo "AT*E2GPSCTL=1,2,1" | sudo dd of=/dev/ttyACM2

# connect to the GPS receiver port and send the start command
screen -L /dev/ttyACM2


echo "AT* " >/dev/ttyACM2

AT*E2GPSCTL?
AT*E2GPSSTAT?
AT*E2GPSPOS?
AT*EEGPSEEDATA?
AT*EEGPSEESTAT?
AT*EEGPSEETEST?
AT*EGPSSAT?
AT*E2GPSNPD


#Screen
C-a = "Control-a", sometimes written "^a"
# List screen sessions
screen -ls
# Reatach session 23520
screen -r 23520
# To Kill
Ctrl+a +K
# OR
screen -X -S 23520 quit


sudo gpsd -V
sudo gpsd --help
sudo gpsd /dev/ttyACM2 -F /var/run/gpsd.sock
sudo gpsd -b -N -D 2 /dev/ttyACM2
sudo gpsd -D 5 -N -n /dev/ttyUSB0
cgps -s


sudo gpsd -N -n -D 2 /dev/ttyACM0
cgps -s
xgps
gpsmon





# Enabling GPS location in ModemManager
https://sigquit.wordpress.com/2012/03/29/enabling-gps-location-in-modemmanager/
mmcli --list-modems
mmcli -m 0 --location-status
sudo mmcli -m 0 --enable
sudo mmcli -m 0 --location-enable-gps-raw --location-enable-gps-nmea
mmcli -m 0 --location-status
sudo mmcli -m 0 --location-get
sudo mmcli -m 0 --location-get-gps-raw




# GPS and Linux
http://manurevah.com/blah/en/p/gps-on-linux


http://www.thinkwiki.org/wiki/Ericsson_F3507g_Mobile_Broadband_Module#Using_the_card_as_a_GPS_receiver


# Plane Plotter Local GPS
http://www.radarspotters.eu/forum/index.php?topic=3962.0

PlanePlotter now features an optional input for a local GPS. If you have a GPS that delivers NMEA format serial data (eg via a USB virtual comm port or Bluetooth), PP can process that data for a number of purposes. You configure
the (virtual) serial port in Options..Home location..GPS setup. You enable the GPS input in Options..I/O settings. In the same dialog there is a an option to log the GPS positions to a GPX file that PP can read. If you are using
the program while mobile, this might be useful to display where you went.

When processing, PP will unconditionally redefine the Home location that PP uses to match the position received from the GPS.

Warning : If you use this feature in a mobile context and then return home, the Home location will need to be restored manually to the correct position before using PP again - unless you can connect the GPS after you arrived home.

There is a new option to centre the display on the current GPS position. This only works while the GPS is connected and operating but could be useful for mobile users.

Finally, there is an option to plot the GPS location as an aircraft symbol. A dummy aircraft with a "hex" code of "ZZZZZZ" shows the latitude, longitude, course and speed (if available from the GPS). This dummy aircraft is not shared through the sharing system. If you have your own aircraft, this might be a useful feature to display a moving map display with the "heavies" overlaid on it. Make sure you read and understand the expanded disclaimer if you feel like trying this. If you enable this feature, the aircraft symbol replaces the normal home location symbol.

# VK-172 USB GPS
# [modemmanager] interferes with gpsd: pls. blacklist newer ublox
########################################################################
https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=798193


sudo nano /lib/udev/rules.d/60-gpsd.rules
########################################################################
# u-blox AG, u-blox 6 (tested with GNSS Evaluation Kit TCXO) [linux module: cdc_acm]
ATTRS{idVendor}=="1546", ATTRS{idProduct}=="01a6", SYMLINK+="gps%n", TAG+="systemd", ENV{SYSTEMD_WANTS}="gpsdctl@%k.service"

# u-blox AG, u-blox 7 (tested with GPS/Glonass ublox-7) [linux module: cdc_acm]
ATTRS{idVendor}=="1546", ATTRS{idProduct}=="01a7", SYMLINK+="gps%n", TAG+="systemd", ENV{SYSTEMD_WANTS}="gpsdctl@%k.service"
########################################################################





sudo nano /lib/udev/rules.d/77-mm-usb-device-blacklist.rules
########################################################################
# u-blox AG, u-blox 6 (tested with GNSS Evaluation Kit TCXO) [linux module: cdc_acm]
ATTRS{idVendor}=="1546", ATTRS{idProduct}=="01a6", SYMLINK+="gps%n", TAG+="systemd", ENV{SYSTEMD_WANTS}="gpsdctl@%k.service"

# u-blox AG, u-blox 7 (tested with GPS/Glonass ublox-7) [linux module: cdc_acm]
ATTRS{idVendor}=="1546", ATTRS{idProduct}=="01a7", SYMLINK+="gps%n", TAG+="systemd", ENV{SYSTEMD_WANTS}="gpsdctl@%k.service"

# u-blox AG, u-blox 8  [linux module: cdc_acm]
ATTRS{idVendor}=="1546", ATTRS{idProduct}=="01a8", SYMLINK+="gps%n", TAG+="systemd", ENV{SYSTEMD_WANTS}="gpsdctl@%k.service"
########################################################################

sudo cat /dev/ttyACM0
sudo gpsd /dev/ttyACM0 -n -F /var/run/gpsd.sock

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
#    How to listen to Radio in the UK - FM | AM (LW and MW) | SW | DAB | DAB+
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
- via Radio Analogue Aerial = on your FM/AM Radio | on your PC = FM/AM/DAB/DAB+ with cheap SDR dongle
- via Radio Digital Aerial = on your DAB/DAB+ Radio |  on your PC = FM/AM/DAB/DAB+ with cheap SDR dongle

- via TV Aerial = DVB-T = only few selected stations on your TV | on your PC with cheap SDR dongle
- via Satelite Dish = DVB-S = only few selected stations on yout TV with DVB-S | on your PC with DVB-S card

- via Internet = radioplayer.co.uk / www.youview.com (limited stations) | on your Internet Radio* | on your PC*
* Some programs are not available outside of UK, if you connect with non-UK IP address.

Linux support for the Psion WaveFinder USB DAB/DAB+ radio
https://sourceforge.net/projects/opendab/




software tools called ODR-mmbTools that can be used to transmit DAB and DAB+.
http://www.opendigitalradio.org/software
http://www.opendigitalradio.org/software


SDR-J is an open-source SDR DAB and DAB+ receiver with a QT GUI that can use the RTL-SDR USB dongles.
http://www.sdr-j.tk/index.html

command-line open source receiver that decodes FIC data.
https://github.com/maydavid/rtl-dab/

Can receive from RTLSDR and write an ETI file. It combines well with dablin and etisnoop.
https://github.com/linuxstb/dabtools

DAB/DAB+ receiver for Linux (including ETI-NI playback)
https://github.com/Opendigitalradio/dablin

Set of GNURadio modules for DAB reception.
https://github.com/andrmuel/gr-dab

Displays this information within a DAB(+) recording
http://www.basicmaster.de/xpadxpert/

1# Download "DAB Player" (check for new version)
http://ukwtv.de/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=281&Itemid=550&jsmallfib=1&dir=JSROOT/dabplayer&download_file=JSROOT/dabplayer/DAB_Player_1-0-2-120_de-en-fr-it-nl-pl.zip
or version that will log everything for debugging:
http://ukwtv.de/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=281&Itemid=550&jsmallfib=1&dir=JSROOT/dabplayer&download_file=JSROOT/dabplayer/DAB_Player_1-0-2-120_de-en-fr-it-nl-pl_withLog.zip



2# Download Microsoft Visual C++ 2015 Redistributable Update 3
- if you have only 32-bit version of Windows download and install only "vc_redist.x86.exe" file.
- if you have 64-bit version of Windows you need to download/install BOTH files for 32|64-bit versions "vc_redist.x64.exe | vc_redist.x86.exe"
https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=53587
 
Microsoft Visual C++ 2015 Redistributable Update 3 RC
https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/download/details.aspx?id=52685



3# Download and install drivers for you SDR dongle, my was:
- 0bda:2838 Realtek Semiconductor Corp. RTL2838 DVB-T

So I downloaded "Treiber2.zip" file with drivers:
http://ukwtv.de/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=281&Itemid=550&jsmallfib=1&dir=JSROOT/dabplayer&download_file=JSROOT/dabplayer/Treiber2.zip

This file "Treiber2_SupportedHw.pdf" describes supported hardware for this driver:
http://ukwtv.de/cms/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=281&Itemid=550&jsmallfib=1&dir=JSROOT/dabplayer&download_file=JSROOT/dabplayer/Treiber2_SupportedHw.pdf



4# Launch the app and scann for available Multiplxes/Ensembles
http://www.wohnort.org/DAB/
http://www.wohnort.org/dab/ukloc.html
http://www.wohnort.org/dab/uknat.html

On the balcony ledge: 6 Ensembles / 71 services (Audio 67, Data 4)

Surrey-NSussex - 10C
SDL National - 11A
D1 National - 11D
BBC National DAB - 12B

Berks & N Hants - 12D
 
Fun Kids UK - AAC 32 kbit/s
Jazz FM Stereo - AAC 32 kbit/s
Magic Chilled - AAC 32 kbit/s
Union JACK AAC 24 kbit/s
JACK 2 Surrey 0x0000C6CD - AAC 32 kbit/s
JACK Surrey 0x0000C5CD - AAC 40 kbit/s

DAB_Player.exe -LogAudioInfo
DAB_Player.exe -LogSnr -LogAudioInfo


Controls:
F1 - Info screen
F2 - Compact view / Full View
F3 - Channel list  On/Off
F4 - Mute
F5 - Vol Down
F6 - Vol Up
F7 - Record  / Stop Recording
F8 - Menu
F9 - Channel search
F10 - Manage pre set channels

#    How to watch a TV in the UK - No Analogue transmission, digital only = DVB-T | DVB-T2 | DVB-S | DVB-S2
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
- via TV Aerial = Freeview = DVB-T | DVB-T2 on your TV | PC with DVB-T | DVB-T2 card
- via Satelite Dish = Freesat box / Freesat from Sky box+card / Satelite box on yout TV | PC with DVB-S/DVB-S2 card
- via Internet | IPTV = www.youview.com / www.btvision.bt.com on you TV with their box | PC via tvcatchup.com etc.


Freeview - DVB-T | DVB-T2
http://www.digitaluk.co.uk/industry/Channels/channel_listings
https://ukfree.tv/transmitters/tv/Crystal_Palace

http://www.digitaluk.co.uk/coveragechecker/main/trade/


Engineering Channel Over-air Download Schedule
http://dtg.org.uk/dtg/dtt.html#oad
DTG Testing administers The Engineering Channel, carried on Multiplex PSB1 and which is used by manufacturers to download software updates to Freeview/DTT receivers.
Over-air downloads scheduled for this week and next are given on the OAD page. A similar system operates for Freesat receivers and the updates currently being broadcast
are listed at the bottom of the page. An RSS feed of the schedule is also available.
http://dtg.org.uk/dtg/download_schedule.html


High Dynamic Range Television and Hybrid Log-Gamma
http://www.bbc.co.uk/rd/projects/high-dynamic-range

A#
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
 Telephone line "copper pair"
xDSL = ADSL (20CN 8Mb/s | 1Mb/s) | ADSL2+ (21CN 24Mb/s | 1Mb/s or  with Annex M 2Mb/s) | VDSL = BT Infinity = FTTC (80Mb/s | 20Mb/s ) |

You still need a "copper pair" = telephone line, but now you do not need to have a "Voice" service on the line, or transfer the number as VoIP number.

My favorite ISP A&A has these options: - No limit on upload, only the download is metered.
Home::1 - http://aa.net.uk/broadband-home1-info.html
1) ADSL 100GB download / month £25 + Landline paid to (BT, TalkTalk,etc. ) OR from A&A for £10 with no voice service + Annex M / month £10 if you need it.
2) VDSL/FTTC 100GB download / month £35 + Landline paid to (BT, TalkTalk,etc. ) OR from A&A for £10 with no voice service

Home::1 Terabyte - http://aa.net.uk/broadband-home1-terabyte.html
3) ADSL 1TB download / month £40 + Landline paid to (BT, TalkTalk,etc. ) OR from A&A for £10 with no voice service + Annex M / month £10 if you need it.
4) VDSL/FTTC 1 TB download  / month £50 + Landline paid to (BT, TalkTalk,etc. ) OR from A&A for £10 with no voice service



Home > Broadband > Services > Annex M = Still charged extra £10/month
http://aa.net.uk/broadband-annexm.html
Home > Broadband
http://aa.net.uk/broadband-TT.html

Upload on Home::1 Terabyte is metered?  No, still un-metered

Phone line tesing 17070 if no voice on line? Dail tone available, but call are blocked. Only service numbers will work.

http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-35869222

Why are people charged for 'landline rental'?
http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-30273667


# BT BROADBAND AVAILABILITY CHECKER
https://www.btwholesale.com/includes/adsl/adsl.htm

You can search by:

A# Telephone Number Checker - Telephone line:
or
B# Telephone Number Checker - Access Line ID:


C# Address Checker - Postcode:
http://www.royalmail.com/find-a-postcode
or
D# Address Checker - Unique Property Reference Number - (UPRN):
•12 digit maximum length  unique  identifier
•Assigned to every unit of land and property recorded by local government
•UPRN  is a feature increasingly  used by Utilities  companies
•Provides improved  identification  of customer properties at locations
•Provides opportunity  to reduce missed appointments
•Used by Ordnance Survey  in their AddressBase products
or
E# Address Checker - Network Address key - (NAD key) + District ID


F# PostCode Checker - Postcode:
Postcode only checks will not return any result for Fibre services (FTTP, FTTC:VDSL and G.fast).
http://www.royalmail.com/find-a-postcode



https://www.btwholesale.com/pages/static/help-and-support/broadband.htm
https://www.btwholesale.com/pages/static/help-and-support/apps.htm
https://www.btwholesale.com/assets/documents/B2B/BTW_Release_AV_Notification_walkthrough_slides_7_7_15.pdf

D#
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Mobile phone operator - 3G = HSDPA, HSxxx / 4G = LTE
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_LTE_networks_in_Europe
http://maps.mobileworldlive.com/network.php?cid=39&cname=United%20Kingdom

Please note, that Mobile Phone Operator now offer 2 types of packages:
- Internet included in yout phone plan - can be cheaper, if you find a good deal, sold as Data add-ons.
- Internet only, no voice on SIM card for Dongles, Pocket Hotspot, Tablets* and iPads that can't make CSD calls sold as Mobile Broadband
* Some tablets will allow you to make CSD calls, but mobile operators will block using phone plans SIM card and insist on buying Mobile Brodband SIM.


4 operator that build their own NATIONWIDE infrastructure:
https://www.o2.co.uk/ - 2G 900Mhz/1800MHz, 3G 2100 MHz, 4G
http://www.vodafone.co.uk/ - 2G 900Mhz/1800MHz, 3G 2100 MHz, 4G
http://ee.co.uk/ - 2G 1800MHz, 3G 2100 MHz, 4G
http://www.three.co.uk/ - 2G Voice Only Roaming in O2, 3G 2100 MHz, 4G 
Three has National Roaming in O2 network in some rural areas.


Three calls for Spectrum cap on EE
http://dtg.org.uk/news/news.html?id=5632


Mobile virtual network operators (MVNOs) in the UK, renting network from any of the 4 above:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_United_Kingdom_mobile_virtual_network_operators

# microSD / microSDXC
